function.name: gdk_char_height
function.description:
Determines the total height of a given character. This value is not generally useful, because you cannot determine how this total height will be drawn in relation to the baseline. See gdk_text_extents().
Deprecated: 2.2: Use gdk_text_extents() instead.
function.return: the height of the character in pixels.

function.name: gdk_add_client_message_filter
function.description: Adds a filter to the default display to be called when X ClientMessage events are received. See gdk_display_add_client_message_filter().

parameter.name: message_type
parameter.parameter_description: the type of ClientMessage events to receive. This will be checked against the <structfield>message_type</structfield> field of the XClientMessage event struct.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call to process the event.

function.name: gdk_display_get_screen
function.description:
Returns a screen object for one of the screens of the display.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the #GdkScreen object

function.name: gdk_x11_screen_get_xscreen
function.description:
Returns the screen of a #GdkScreen.
Since: 2.2
function.return: an Xlib <type>Screen*</type>

function.name: gdk_selection_send_notify_for_display
function.description:
Send a response to SelectionRequest event.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: requestor
parameter.parameter_description: window to which to deliver response.

parameter.name: property
parameter.parameter_description: property in which the selection owner stored the data, or %GDK_NONE to indicate that the request was rejected.

function.name: gdk_window_move_region
function.description:
Move the part of @window indicated by @region by @dy pixels in the Y direction and @dx pixels in the X direction. The portions of @region that not covered by the new position of @region are invalidated.
Child windows are not moved.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: dx
parameter.parameter_description: Amount to move in the X direction

parameter.name: dy
parameter.parameter_description: Amount to move in the Y direction

function.name: gdk_screen_width
function.description: Returns the width of the default screen in pixels.
function.return: the width of the default screen in pixels.

function.name: gdk_gc_get_values
function.description:
Retrieves the current values from a graphics context. Note that only the pixel values of the @values->foreground and @values->background are filled, use gdk_colormap_query_color() to obtain the rgb values if you need them.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use Cairo for rendering.

parameter.name: values
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkGCValues structure in which to store the results.

function.name: gdk_region_point_in
function.description: Finds out if a point is in a region.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of a point

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of a point

function.return: %TRUE if the point is in @region.

function.name: gdk_colors_free
function.description: Frees colors allocated with gdk_colors_alloc(). This function is obsolete. See gdk_colormap_free_colors().

parameter.name: pixels
parameter.parameter_description: the pixel values of the colors to free.

parameter.name: planes
parameter.parameter_description: the plane masks for all planes to free, OR'd together.

function.name: gdk_pixmap_create_from_xpm
function.description:
Create a pixmap from a XPM file.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use a #GdkPixbuf instead. You can use gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file() to create it. If you must use a pixmap, use gdk_pixmap_new() to create it and Cairo to draw the pixbuf onto it.

parameter.name: drawable
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkDrawable, used to determine default values for the new pixmap.

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: (out) a pointer to a place to store a bitmap representing the transparency mask of the XPM file. Can be %NULL, in which case transparency will be ignored.

parameter.name: transparent_color
parameter.parameter_description: the color to be used for the pixels that are transparent in the input file. Can be %NULL, in which case a default color will be used.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: the filename of a file containing XPM data.

function.return: the #GdkPixmap

function.name: gdk_x11_cursor_get_xcursor
function.description: Returns the X cursor belonging to a #GdkCursor.
function.return: an Xlib <type>Cursor</type>.

function.name: gdk_drag_status
function.description:
Selects one of the actions offered by the drag source.
This function is called by the drag destination in response to gdk_drag_motion() called by the drag source.

parameter.name: action
parameter.parameter_description: the selected action which will be taken when a drop happens, or 0 to indicate that a drop will not be accepted.

function.name: gdk_window_shape_combine_mask
function.description:
Applies a shape mask to @window. Pixels in @window corresponding to set bits in the @mask will be visible; pixels in @window corresponding to unset bits in the @mask will be transparent. This gives a non-rectangular window.
If @mask is %NULL, the shape mask will be unset, and the @x/@y parameters are not used.
On the X11 platform, this uses an X server extension which is widely available on most common platforms, but not available on very old X servers, and occasionally the implementation will be buggy. On servers without the shape extension, this function will do nothing.
This function works on both toplevel and child windows.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: X position of shape mask with respect to @window

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: Y position of shape mask with respect to @window

function.name: gdk_app_launch_context_set_screen
function.description:
Sets the screen on which applications will be launched when using this context. See also gdk_app_launch_context_set_display().
If both @screen and @display are set, the @screen takes priority. If neither @screen or @display are set, the default screen and display are used.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gdk_event_get
function.description: Checks all open displays for a #GdkEvent to process,to be processed on, fetching events from the windowing system if necessary. See gdk_display_get_event().
function.return: the next #GdkEvent to be processed, or %NULL if no events are pending. The returned #GdkEvent should be freed with gdk_event_free().

function.name: gdk_gc_set_clip_rectangle
function.description:
Sets the clip mask for a graphics context from a rectangle. The clip mask is interpreted relative to the clip origin. (See gdk_gc_set_clip_origin()).
Deprecated: 2.22: Use cairo_rectangle() and cairo_clip() in Cairo.

function.name: gdk_display_get_default_group
function.description:
Returns the default group leader window for all toplevel windows on @display. This window is implicitly created by GDK. See gdk_window_set_group().
Since: 2.4
function.return: The default group leader window for @display

function.name: gdk_gc_new_with_values
function.description:
Create a new GC with the given initial values.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use Cairo for rendering.

parameter.name: drawable
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkDrawable. The created GC must always be used with drawables of the same depth as this one.

parameter.name: values
parameter.parameter_description: a structure containing initial values for the GC.

parameter.name: values_mask
parameter.parameter_description: a bit mask indicating which fields in @values are set.

function.return: the new graphics context.

function.name: gdk_image_get_visual
function.description:
Determines the visual that was used to create the image.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 2.22: #GdkImage should not be used anymore.
function.return: a #GdkVisual

function.name: gdk_drag_context_unref
function.description:
Deprecated function; use g_object_unref() instead.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_object_unref() instead.

function.name: gdk_pango_renderer_set_gc
function.description:
Sets the GC the renderer draws with. Note that the GC must not be modified until it is unset by calling the function again with %NULL for the @gc parameter, since GDK may make internal copies of the GC which won't be updated to follow changes to the original GC.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: gc
parameter.parameter_description: the new GC to use for drawing, or %NULL

function.name: gdk_spawn_on_screen_with_pipes
function.description:
Like g_spawn_async_with_pipes(), except the child process is spawned in such an environment that on calling gdk_display_open() it would be returned a #GdkDisplay with @screen as the default screen.
This is useful for applications which wish to launch an application on a specific screen.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: working_directory
parameter.parameter_description: child's current working directory, or %NULL to inherit parent's

parameter.name: envp
parameter.parameter_description: child's environment, or %NULL to inherit parent's

parameter.name: child_setup
parameter.parameter_description: function to run in the child just before exec()

parameter.name: child_pid
parameter.parameter_description: return location for child process ID, or %NULL

parameter.name: standard_input
parameter.parameter_description: return location for file descriptor to write to child's stdin, or %NULL

parameter.name: standard_output
parameter.parameter_description: return location for file descriptor to read child's stdout, or %NULL

parameter.name: standard_error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for file descriptor to read child's stderr, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE if an error was set

function.name: gdk_display_get_default_screen
function.description:
Get the default #GdkScreen for @display.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the default #GdkScreen object for @display

function.name: gdk_screen_height
function.description: Returns the height of the default screen in pixels.
function.return: the height of the default screen in pixels.

function.name: gdk_window_new
function.description: Creates a new #GdkWindow using the attributes from @attributes. See #GdkWindowAttr and #GdkWindowAttributesType for more details. Note: to use this on displays other than the default display, @parent must be specified.

parameter.name: parent
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkWindow, or %NULL to create the window as a child of the default root window for the default display.

parameter.name: attributes_mask
parameter.parameter_description: mask indicating which fields in @attributes are valid

function.return: the new #GdkWindow

function.name: gdk_window_get_update_area
function.description: Transfers ownership of the update area from @window to the caller of the function. That is, after calling this function, @window will no longer have an invalid/dirty region; the update area is removed from @window and handed to you. If a window has no update area, gdk_window_get_update_area() returns %NULL. You are responsible for calling gdk_region_destroy() on the returned region if it's non-%NULL.
function.return: the update area for @window

function.name: gdk_colormap_ref
function.description:
Deprecated function; use g_object_ref() instead.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_ref() instead.
function.return: the colormap

function.name: gdk_font_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count of a font by one. If the result is zero, destroys the font.

function.name: gdk_offscreen_window_get_pixmap
function.description:
Gets the offscreen pixmap that an offscreen window renders into. If you need to keep this around over window resizes, you need to add a reference to it.
Since: 2.18
function.return: The offscreen pixmap, or %NULL if not offscreen

function.name: gdk_window_foreign_new_for_display
function.description:
Wraps a native window in a #GdkWindow. This may fail if the window has been destroyed. If the window was already known to GDK, a new reference to the existing #GdkWindow is returned.
For example in the X backend, a native window handle is an Xlib <type>XID</type>.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkDisplay where the window handle comes from.

function.return: a #GdkWindow wrapper for the native window or %NULL if the window has been destroyed. The wrapper will be newly created, if one doesn't exist already.

function.name: gdk_window_get_focus_on_map
function.description:
Determines whether or not the desktop environment should be hinted that the window does not want to receive input focus when it is mapped.
Since: 2.22
function.return: whether or not the window wants to receive input focus when it is mapped.

function.name: gdk_pango_attr_emboss_color_new
function.description:
Creates a new attribute specifying the color to emboss text with.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: a GdkColor representing the color to emboss with

function.return: new #PangoAttribute

function.name: gdk_x11_drawable_get_xdisplay
function.description: Returns the display of a #GdkDrawable.
function.return: an Xlib <type>Display*</type>.

function.name: gdk_utf8_to_string_target
function.description: Converts an UTF-8 string into the best possible representation as a STRING. The representation of characters not in STRING is not specified; it may be as pseudo-escape sequences \x{ABCD}, or it may be in some other form of approximation.
function.return: the newly-allocated string, or %NULL if the conversion failed. (It should not fail for any properly formed UTF-8 string unless system limits like memory or file descriptors are exceeded.)

function.name: gdk_display_get_default_cursor_size
function.description:
Returns the default size to use for cursors on @display.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the default cursor size.

function.name: gdk_drag_context_list_targets
function.description:
Retrieves the list of targets of the context.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GList of targets

function.name: gdk_device_get_source
function.description:
Determines the type of the device.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GdkInputSource

function.name: gdk_set_pointer_hooks
function.description:
This function allows for hooking into the operation of getting the current location of the pointer. This is only useful for such low-level tools as an event recorder. Applications should never have any reason to use this facility.
This function is not multihead safe. For multihead operation, see gdk_display_set_pointer_hooks().

parameter.name: new_hooks
parameter.parameter_description: a table of pointers to functions for getting quantities related to the current pointer position, or %NULL to restore the default table.

function.return: the previous pointer hook table

function.name: gdk_display_set_double_click_distance
function.description:
Sets the double click distance (two clicks within this distance count as a double click and result in a #GDK_2BUTTON_PRESS event). See also gdk_display_set_double_click_time(). Applications should <emphasis>not</emphasis> set this, it is a global user-configured setting.
Since: 2.4

function.name: gdk_screen_get_number
function.description:
Gets the index of @screen among the screens in the display to which it belongs. (See gdk_screen_get_display())
Since: 2.2
function.return: the index

function.name: gdk_device_get_mode
function.description:
Determines the mode of the device.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GdkInputSource

function.name: gdk_colormap_free_colors
function.description: Frees previously allocated colors.

function.name: gdk_test_simulate_key
function.description: This function is intended to be used in Gtk+ test programs. If (@x,@y) are > (-1,-1), it will warp the mouse pointer to the given (@x,@y) corrdinates within @window and simulate a key press or release event. When the mouse pointer is warped to the target location, use of this function outside of test programs that run in their own virtual windowing system (e.g. Xvfb) is not recommended. If (@x,@y) are passed as (-1,-1), the mouse pointer will not be warped and @window origin will be used as mouse pointer location for the event. Also, gtk_test_simulate_key() is a fairly low level function, for most testing purposes, gtk_test_widget_send_key() is the right function to call which will generate a key press event followed by its accompanying key release event.

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: Gdk window to simulate a key event for.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: x coordinate within @window for the key event.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: y coordinate within @window for the key event.

parameter.name: modifiers
parameter.parameter_description: Keyboard modifiers the event is setup with.

function.return: wether all actions neccessary for a key event simulation were carried out successfully.

function.name: gdk_x11_window_set_user_time
function.description:
The application can use this call to update the _NET_WM_USER_TIME property on a toplevel window. This property stores an Xserver time which represents the time of the last user input event received for this window. This property may be used by the window manager to alter the focus, stacking, and/or placement behavior of windows when they are mapped depending on whether the new window was created by a user action or is a "pop-up" window activated by a timer or some other event.
Note that this property is automatically updated by GDK, so this function should only be used by applications which handle input events bypassing GDK.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: An XServer timestamp to which the property should be set

function.name: gdk_window_configure_finished
function.description:
Signal to the window system that the application has finished handling Configure events it has received. Window Managers can use this to better synchronize the frame repaint with the application. GTK+ applications will automatically call this function when appropriate.
This function can only be called if gdk_window_enable_synchronized_configure() was called previously.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gdk_screen_get_n_monitors
function.description:
Returns the number of monitors which @screen consists of.
Since: 2.2
function.return: number of monitors which @screen consists of

function.name: gdk_screen_get_setting
function.description:
Retrieves a desktop-wide setting such as double-click time for the #GdkScreen @screen.
FIXME needs a list of valid settings here, or a link to more information.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: screen
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkScreen where the setting is located

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the value of the setting

function.return: %TRUE if the setting existed and a value was stored in @value, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_image_get_pixels
function.description:
Returns a pointer to the pixel data of the image.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 2.22: #GdkImage should not be used anymore.
function.return: the pixel data of the image

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_for_display
function.description:
Returns the #GdkKeymap attached to @display.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the #GdkKeymap attached to @display.

function.name: gdk_font_equal
function.description: Compares two fonts for equality. Single fonts compare equal if they have the same X font ID. This operation does not currently work correctly for fontsets.
function.return: %TRUE if the fonts are equal.

function.name: gdk_gc_set_tile
function.description:
Set a tile pixmap for a graphics context. This will only be used if the fill mode is %GDK_TILED.
Deprecated: 2.22: The following code snippet sets a tiling #GdkPixmap as the source in Cairo: |[gdk_cairo_set_source_pixmap (cr, tile, ts_origin_x, ts_origin_y); cairo_pattern_set_extend (cairo_get_source (cr), CAIRO_EXTEND_REPEAT);]|

function.name: gdk_x11_gc_get_xgc
function.description:
Returns the X GC of a #GdkGC.
Deprecated: 2.22: #GdkGC has been replaced by #cairo_t.
function.return: an Xlib <type>GC</type>.

function.name: gdk_gc_set_rgb_fg_color
function.description:
Set the foreground color of a GC using an unallocated color. The pixel value for the color will be determined using GdkRGB. If the colormap for the GC has not previously been initialized for GdkRGB, then for pseudo-color colormaps (colormaps with a small modifiable number of colors), a colorcube will be allocated in the colormap.
Calling this function for a GC without a colormap is an error.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use gdk_cairo_set_source_color() instead.

function.name: gdk_window_begin_move_drag
function.description: Begins a window move operation (for a toplevel window). You might use this function to implement a "window move grip," for example. The function works best with window managers that support the <ulink url="http://www.freedesktop.org/Standards/wm-spec">Extended Window Manager Hints</ulink>, but has a fallback implementation for other window managers.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the button being used to drag

parameter.name: root_x
parameter.parameter_description: root window X coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: root_y
parameter.parameter_description: root window Y coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: timestamp of mouse click that began the drag

function.name: gdk_visual_get_best_depth
function.description: Get the best available depth for the default GDK screen. "Best" means "largest," i.e. 32 preferred over 24 preferred over 8 bits per pixel.
function.return: best available depth

function.name: gdk_colors_store
function.description: Changes the value of the first @ncolors colors in a private colormap. This function is obsolete and should not be used. See gdk_color_change().

parameter.name: ncolors
parameter.parameter_description: the number of colors to change.

function.name: gdk_font_from_description_for_display
function.description:
Loads a #GdkFont based on a Pango font description for use on @display. This font will only be an approximation of the Pango font, and internationalization will not be handled correctly. This function should only be used for legacy code that cannot be easily converted to use Pango. Using Pango directly will produce better results.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the newly loaded font, or %NULL if the font cannot be loaded.

function.name: gdk_set_double_click_time
function.description: Set the double click time for the default display. See gdk_display_set_double_click_time(). See also gdk_display_set_double_click_distance(). Applications should <emphasis>not</emphasis> set this, it is a global user-configured setting.

parameter.name: msec
parameter.parameter_description: double click time in milliseconds (thousandths of a second)

function.name: gdk_font_load
function.description:
Loads a font.
The font may be newly loaded or looked up the font in a cache. You should make no assumptions about the initial reference count.

parameter.name: font_name
parameter.parameter_description: a XLFD describing the font to load.

function.return: a #GdkFont, or %NULL if the font could not be loaded.

function.name: gdk_region_spans_intersect_foreach
function.description:
Calls a function on each span in the intersection of @region and @spans.
Deprecated: 2.22: There is no replacement.

parameter.name: sorted
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if @spans is sorted wrt. the y coordinate

parameter.name: function
parameter.parameter_description: function to call on each span in the intersection

function.name: gdk_image_get_byte_order
function.description:
Determines the byte order of the image.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 2.22: #GdkImage should not be used anymore.
function.return: a #GdkVisual

function.name: gdk_display_get_name
function.description:
Gets the name of the display.
Since: 2.2
function.return: a string representing the display name. This string is owned by GDK and should not be modified or freed.

function.name: gdk_rectangle_union
function.description: Calculates the union of two rectangles. The union of rectangles @src1 and @src2 is the smallest rectangle which includes both @src1 and @src2 within it. It is allowed for @dest to be the same as either @src1 or @src2.

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the union of @src1 and @src2

function.name: gdk_device_get_axis
function.description: Interprets an array of double as axis values for a given device, and locates the value in the array for a given axis use.

parameter.name: axes
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to an array of axes

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the found value.

function.return: %TRUE if the given axis use was found, otherwise %FALSE

function.name: gdk_pixmap_create_from_xpm_d
function.description:
Create a pixmap from data in XPM format.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use a #GdkPixbuf instead. You can use gdk_pixbuf_new_from_xpm_data() to create it. If you must use a pixmap, use gdk_pixmap_new() to create it and Cairo to draw the pixbuf onto it.

parameter.name: drawable
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkDrawable, used to determine default values for the new pixmap.

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a place to store a bitmap representing the transparency mask of the XPM file. Can be %NULL, in which case transparency will be ignored.

parameter.name: transparent_color
parameter.parameter_description: This color will be used for the pixels that are transparent in the input file. Can be %NULL in which case a default color will be used.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a string containing the XPM data.

function.return: the #GdkPixmap.

function.name: gdk_set_show_events
function.description: Sets whether a trace of received events is output. Note that GTK+ must be compiled with debugging (that is, configured using the <option>--enable-debug</option> option) to use this option.

function.name: gdk_x11_get_server_time
function.description: Routine to get the current X server time stamp.

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkWindow, used for communication with the server. The window must have GDK_PROPERTY_CHANGE_MASK in its events mask or a hang will result.

function.return: the time stamp.

function.name: gdk_x11_ungrab_server
function.description: Ungrab the default display after it has been grabbed with gdk_x11_grab_server().

function.name: gdk_window_get_position
function.description:
Obtains the position of the window as reported in the most-recently-processed #GdkEventConfigure. Contrast with gdk_window_get_geometry() which queries the X server for the current window position, regardless of which events have been received or processed.
The position coordinates are relative to the window's parent window.

function.name: gdk_cursor_ref
function.description: Adds a reference to @cursor.
function.return: Same @cursor that was passed in

function.name: gdk_region_xor
function.description: Sets the area of @source1 to the exclusive-OR of the areas of @source1 and @source2. The resulting area is the set of pixels contained in one or the other of the two sources but not in both.

function.name: gdk_drag_abort
function.description:
Aborts a drag without dropping.
This function is called by the drag source.

function.name: gdk_draw_layout_with_colors
function.description:
Render a #PangoLayout onto a #GdkDrawable, overriding the layout's normal colors with @foreground and/or @background. @foreground and @background need not be allocated.
If the layout's #PangoContext has a transformation matrix set, then @x and @y specify the position of the top left corner of the bounding box (in device space) of the transformed layout.
If you're using GTK+, the ususal way to obtain a #PangoLayout is gtk_widget_create_pango_layout().

parameter.name: drawable
parameter.parameter_description: the drawable on which to draw string

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X position of the left of the layout (in pixels)

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y position of the top of the layout (in pixels)

parameter.name: foreground
parameter.parameter_description: foreground override color, or %NULL for none

parameter.name: background
parameter.parameter_description: background override color, or %NULL for none

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_from_drawable
function.description:
Transfers image data from a #GdkDrawable and converts it to an RGB(A) representation inside a #GdkPixbuf. In other words, copies image data from a server-side drawable to a client-side RGB(A) buffer. This allows you to efficiently read individual pixels on the client side.
If the drawable @src has no colormap (gdk_drawable_get_colormap() returns %NULL), then a suitable colormap must be specified. Typically a #GdkWindow or a pixmap created by passing a #GdkWindow to gdk_pixmap_new() will already have a colormap associated with it. If the drawable has a colormap, the @cmap argument will be ignored. If the drawable is a bitmap (1 bit per pixel pixmap), then a colormap is not required; pixels with a value of 1 are assumed to be white, and pixels with a value of 0 are assumed to be black. For taking screenshots, gdk_colormap_get_system() returns the correct colormap to use.
If the specified destination pixbuf @dest is %NULL, then this function will create an RGB pixbuf with 8 bits per channel and no alpha, with the same size specified by the @width and @height arguments. In this case, the @dest_x and @dest_y arguments must be specified as 0. If the specified destination pixbuf is not %NULL and it contains alpha information, then the filled pixels will be set to full opacity (alpha = 255).
If the specified drawable is a pixmap, then the requested source rectangle must be completely contained within the pixmap, otherwise the function will return %NULL. For pixmaps only (not for windows) passing -1 for width or height is allowed to mean the full width or height of the pixmap.
If the specified drawable is a window, and the window is off the screen, then there is no image data in the obscured/offscreen regions to be placed in the pixbuf. The contents of portions of the pixbuf corresponding to the offscreen region are undefined.
If the window you're obtaining data from is partially obscured by other windows, then the contents of the pixbuf areas corresponding to the obscured regions are undefined.
If the target drawable is not mapped (typically because it's iconified/minimized or not on the current workspace), then %NULL will be returned.
If memory can't be allocated for the return value, %NULL will be returned instead.
(In short, there are several ways this function can fail, and if it fails it returns %NULL; so check the return value.)
This function calls gdk_drawable_get_image() internally and converts the resulting image to a #GdkPixbuf, so the documentation for gdk_drawable_get_image() may also be relevant.

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: Destination pixbuf, or %NULL if a new pixbuf should be created.

parameter.name: cmap
parameter.parameter_description: A colormap if @src doesn't have one set.

parameter.name: dest_x
parameter.parameter_description: Destination X coordinate in pixbuf, or 0 if @dest is NULL.

parameter.name: dest_y
parameter.parameter_description: Destination Y coordinate in pixbuf, or 0 if @dest is NULL.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width in pixels of region to get.

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height in pixels of region to get.

function.return: The same pixbuf as @dest if it was non-%NULL, or a newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1 if no destination pixbuf was specified, or %NULL on error

function.name: gdk_window_get_children
function.description:
Gets the list of children of @window known to GDK. This function only returns children created via GDK, so for example it's useless when used with the root window; it only returns windows an application created itself.
The returned list must be freed, but the elements in the list need not be.
function.return: list of child windows inside @window

function.name: gdk_screen_width_mm
function.description: Returns the width of the default screen in millimeters. Note that on many X servers this value will not be correct.
function.return: the width of the default screen in millimeters, though it is not always correct.

function.name: gdk_text_property_to_text_list_for_display
function.description:
Convert a text string from the encoding as it is stored in a property into an array of strings in the encoding of the current locale. (The elements of the array represent the nul-separated elements of the original text string.)
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: The #GdkDisplay where the encoding is defined.

parameter.name: encoding
parameter.parameter_description: an atom representing the encoding. The most common values for this are STRING, or COMPOUND_TEXT. This is value used as the type for the property.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: The number of items to transform.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: location to store a terminated array of strings in the encoding of the current locale. This array should be freed using gdk_free_text_list().

function.return: the number of strings stored in list, or 0, if the conversion failed.

function.name: gdk_screen_get_toplevel_windows
function.description:
Obtains a list of all toplevel windows known to GDK on the screen @screen. A toplevel window is a child of the root window (see gdk_get_default_root_window()).
The returned list should be freed with g_list_free(), but its elements need not be freed.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: screen
parameter.parameter_description: The #GdkScreen where the toplevels are located.

function.return: list of toplevel windows, free with g_list_free()

function.name: gdk_display_get_n_screens
function.description:
Gets the number of screen managed by the @display.
Since: 2.2
function.return: number of screens.

function.name: gdk_x11_display_ungrab
function.description:
Ungrab @display after it has been grabbed with gdk_x11_display_grab().
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_x11_display_get_user_time
function.description:
Returns the timestamp of the last user interaction on @display. The timestamp is taken from events caused by user interaction such as key presses or pointer movements. See gdk_x11_window_set_user_time().
Since: 2.8
function.return: the timestamp of the last user interaction

function.name: gdk_x11_image_get_xdisplay
function.description: Returns the display of a #GdkImage.
function.return: an Xlib <type>Display*</type>.

function.name: gdk_cairo_set_source_pixmap
function.description:
Sets the given pixmap as the source pattern for the Cairo context. The pattern has an extend mode of %CAIRO_EXTEND_NONE and is aligned so that the origin of @pixmap is @pixmap_x, @pixmap_y
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: pixmap_x
parameter.parameter_description: X coordinate of location to place upper left corner of @pixmap

parameter.name: pixmap_y
parameter.parameter_description: Y coordinate of location to place upper left corner of @pixmap

function.name: gdk_display_put_event
function.description:
Appends a copy of the given event onto the front of the event queue for @display.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_region_rectangle
function.description: Creates a new region containing the area @rectangle.
function.return: a new region

function.name: gdk_window_get_root_coords
function.description:
Obtains the position of a window position in root window coordinates. This is similar to gdk_window_get_origin() but allows you go pass in any position in the window, not just the origin.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gdk_gc_set_font
function.description: Sets the font for a graphics context. (Note that all text-drawing functions in GDK take a @font argument; the value set here is used when that argument is %NULL.)

function.name: gdk_screen_get_default_colormap
function.description:
Gets the default colormap for @screen.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the default #GdkColormap.

function.name: gdk_offscreen_window_get_embedder
function.description:
Gets the window that @window is embedded in.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the embedding #GdkWindow, or %NULL if @window is not an embedded offscreen window

function.name: gdk_mbstowcs
function.description: Converts a multi-byte string to a wide character string. (The function name comes from an acronym of 'Multi-Byte String TO Wide Character String').

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: the space to place the converted wide character string into.

parameter.name: src
parameter.parameter_description: the multi-byte string to convert, which must be nul-terminated.

parameter.name: dest_max
parameter.parameter_description: the maximum number of wide characters to place in @dest.

function.return: the number of wide characters written into @dest, or -1 if the conversion failed.

function.name: gdk_window_set_opacity
function.description:
Request the windowing system to make @window partially transparent, with opacity 0 being fully transparent and 1 fully opaque. (Values of the opacity parameter are clamped to the [0,1] range.)
On X11, this works only on X screens with a compositing manager running.
For setting up per-pixel alpha, see gdk_screen_get_rgba_colormap(). For making non-toplevel windows translucent, see gdk_window_set_composited().
Since: 2.12

function.name: gdk_pango_context_set_colormap
function.description: This function used to set the colormap to be used for drawing with @context. The colormap is now always derived from the graphics context used for drawing, so calling this function is no longer necessary.

function.name: gdk_window_geometry_changed
function.description:
This function informs GDK that the geometry of an embedded offscreen window has changed. This is necessary for GDK to keep track of which offscreen window the pointer is in.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gdk_threads_add_timeout_full

parameter.name: priority
parameter.parameter_description: the priority of the timeout source. Typically this will be in the range between #G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT_IDLE and #G_PRIORITY_HIGH_IDLE.

parameter.name: interval
parameter.parameter_description: the time between calls to the function, in milliseconds (1/1000ths of a second)

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: function to call when the timeout is removed, or %NULL

function.return: the ID (greater than 0) of the event source.

function.name: gdk_threads_init
function.description:
Initializes GDK so that it can be used from multiple threads in conjunction with gdk_threads_enter() and gdk_threads_leave(). g_thread_init() must be called previous to this function.
This call must be made before any use of the main loop from GTK+; to be safe, call it before gtk_init().

function.name: gdk_draw_pixbuf
function.description:
Renders a rectangular portion of a pixbuf to a drawable. The destination drawable must have a colormap. All windows have a colormap, however, pixmaps only have colormap by default if they were created with a non-%NULL window argument. Otherwise a colormap must be set on them with gdk_drawable_set_colormap().
On older X servers, rendering pixbufs with an alpha channel involves round trips to the X server, and may be somewhat slow.
If GDK is built with the Sun mediaLib library, the gdk_draw_pixbuf function is accelerated using mediaLib, which provides hardware acceleration on Intel, AMD, and Sparc chipsets. If desired, mediaLib support can be turned off by setting the GDK_DISABLE_MEDIALIB environment variable.
Since: 2.2
Deprecated: 2.22: Use gdk_cairo_set_source_pixbuf() and cairo_paint() or cairo_rectangle() and cairo_fill() instead.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of region to render, in pixels, or -1 to use pixbuf width.

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of region to render, in pixels, or -1 to use pixbuf height.

function.name: gdk_pixmap_foreign_new_for_display
function.description:
Wraps a native pixmap in a #GdkPixmap. This may fail if the pixmap has been destroyed.
For example in the X backend, a native pixmap handle is an Xlib <type>XID</type>.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the newly-created #GdkPixmap wrapper for the native pixmap or %NULL if the pixmap has been destroyed.

function.name: gdk_window_get_internal_paint_info
function.description:
If you bypass the GDK layer and use windowing system primitives to draw directly onto a #GdkWindow, then you need to deal with two details: there may be an offset between GDK coordinates and windowing system coordinates, and GDK may have redirected drawing to a offscreen pixmap as the result of a gdk_window_begin_paint_region() calls. This function allows retrieving the information you need to compensate for these effects.
This function exposes details of the GDK implementation, and is thus likely to change in future releases of GDK.

parameter.name: real_drawable
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the drawable to which drawing should be done.

parameter.name: x_offset
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the X offset between coordinates in @window, and the underlying window system primitive coordinates for *@real_drawable.

parameter.name: y_offset
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the Y offset between coordinates in @window, and the underlying window system primitive coordinates for *@real_drawable.

function.name: gdk_gc_set_foreground
function.description:
Sets the foreground color for a graphics context. Note that this function uses @color->pixel, use gdk_gc_set_rgb_fg_color() to specify the foreground color as red, green, blue components.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use gdk_cairo_set_source_color() to use a #GdkColor as the source in Cairo.

function.name: gdk_screen_get_default
function.description:
Gets the default screen for the default display. (See gdk_display_get_default ()).
Since: 2.2
function.return: a #GdkScreen, or %NULL if there is no default display.

function.name: gdk_color_hash
function.description: A hash function suitable for using for a hash table that stores #GdkColor's.
function.return: The hash function applied to @colora

function.name: gdk_event_set_screen
function.description:
Sets the screen for @event to @screen. The event must have been allocated by GTK+, for instance, by gdk_event_copy().
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_event_get_axis
function.description: Extract the axis value for a particular axis use from an event structure.

parameter.name: axis_use
parameter.parameter_description: the axis use to look for

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the value found

function.return: %TRUE if the specified axis was found, otherwise %FALSE

function.name: gdk_screen_get_monitor_geometry
function.description:
Retrieves the #GdkRectangle representing the size and position of the individual monitor within the entire screen area.
Note that the size of the entire screen area can be retrieved via gdk_screen_get_width() and gdk_screen_get_height().
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: monitor_num
parameter.parameter_description: the monitor number, between 0 and gdk_screen_get_n_monitors (screen)

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRectangle to be filled with the monitor geometry

function.name: gdk_pango_context_get
function.description:
Creates a #PangoContext for the default GDK screen.
The context must be freed when you're finished with it.
When using GTK+, normally you should use gtk_widget_get_pango_context() instead of this function, to get the appropriate context for the widget you intend to render text onto.
The newly created context will have the default font options (see #cairo_font_options_t) for the default screen; if these options change it will not be updated. Using gtk_widget_get_pango_context() is more convenient if you want to keep a context around and track changes to the screen's font rendering settings.
function.return: a new #PangoContext for the default display

function.name: gdk_color_black
function.description: Returns the black color for a given colormap. The resulting value has already been allocated.

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: the location to store the color.

function.return: %TRUE if the allocation succeeded.

function.name: gdk_window_clear_area_e
function.description:
Like gdk_window_clear_area(), but also generates an expose event for the cleared area.
This function has a stupid name because it dates back to the mists time, pre-GDK-1.0.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: x coordinate of rectangle to clear

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: y coordinate of rectangle to clear

function.name: gdk_display_warp_pointer
function.description:
Warps the pointer of @display to the point @x,@y on the screen @screen, unless the pointer is confined to a window by a grab, in which case it will be moved as far as allowed by the grab. Warping the pointer creates events as if the user had moved the mouse instantaneously to the destination.
Note that the pointer should normally be under the control of the user. This function was added to cover some rare use cases like keyboard navigation support for the color picker in the #GtkColorSelectionDialog.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: screen
parameter.parameter_description: the screen of @display to warp the pointer to

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the destination

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the destination

function.name: gdk_gc_offset
function.description:
Offset attributes such as the clip and tile-stipple origins of the GC so that drawing at x - x_offset, y - y_offset with the offset GC has the same effect as drawing at x, y with the original GC.
Deprecated: 2.22: There is no direct replacement, as this is just a convenience function for gdk_gc_set_ts_origin and gdk_gc_set_clip_origin().

parameter.name: x_offset
parameter.parameter_description: amount by which to offset the GC in the X direction

parameter.name: y_offset
parameter.parameter_description: amount by which to offset the GC in the Y direction

function.name: gdk_image_get
function.description: This is a deprecated wrapper for gdk_drawable_get_image(); gdk_drawable_get_image() should be used instead. Or even better: in most cases gdk_pixbuf_get_from_drawable() is the most convenient choice.
function.return: a new #GdkImage or %NULL

function.name: gdk_font_id
function.description: Returns the X Font ID for the given font.
function.return: the numeric X Font ID

function.name: gdk_window_lookup
function.description:
Looks up the #GdkWindow that wraps the given native window handle.
For example in the X backend, a native window handle is an Xlib <type>XID</type>.
function.return: the #GdkWindow wrapper for the native window, or %NULL if there is none.

function.name: gdk_image_get_bytes_per_pixel
function.description:
Determines the number of bytes per pixel of the image.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 2.22: #GdkImage should not be used anymore.
function.return: the bytes per pixel

function.name: gdk_region_intersect
function.description: Sets the area of @source1 to the intersection of the areas of @source1 and @source2. The resulting area is the set of pixels contained in both @source1 and @source2.

function.name: gdk_text_property_to_utf8_list_for_display
function.description:
Converts a text property in the given encoding to a list of UTF-8 strings.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: encoding
parameter.parameter_description: an atom representing the encoding of the text

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the list of strings or %NULL. The list should be freed with g_strfreev().

function.return: the number of strings in the resulting list.

function.name: gdk_window_set_events
function.description: The event mask for a window determines which events will be reported for that window. For example, an event mask including #GDK_BUTTON_PRESS_MASK means the window should report button press events. The event mask is the bitwise OR of values from the #GdkEventMask enumeration.

function.name: gdk_window_set_keep_above
function.description:
Set if @window must be kept above other windows. If the window was already above, then this function does nothing.
On X11, asks the window manager to keep @window above, if the window manager supports this operation. Not all window managers support this, and some deliberately ignore it or don't have a concept of "keep above"; so you can't rely on the window being kept above. But it will happen with most standard window managers, and GDK makes a best effort to get it to happen.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: whether to keep @window above other windows

function.name: gdk_window_set_debug_updates
function.description:
With update debugging enabled, calls to gdk_window_invalidate_region() clear the invalidated region of the screen to a noticeable color, and GDK pauses for a short time before sending exposes to windows during gdk_window_process_updates(). The net effect is that you can see the invalid region for each window and watch redraws as they occur. This allows you to diagnose inefficiencies in your application.
In essence, because the GDK rendering model prevents all flicker, if you are redrawing the same region 400 times you may never notice, aside from noticing a speed problem. Enabling update debugging causes GTK to flicker slowly and noticeably, so you can see exactly what's being redrawn when, in what order.
The --gtk-debug=updates command line option passed to GTK+ programs enables this debug option at application startup time. That's usually more useful than calling gdk_window_set_debug_updates() yourself, though you might want to use this function to enable updates sometime after application startup time.

function.name: gdk_drag_context_ref
function.description:
Deprecated function; use g_object_ref() instead.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_object_ref() instead.

function.name: gdk_get_default_root_window
function.description: Obtains the root window (parent all other windows are inside) for the default display and screen.
function.return: the default root window

function.name: gdk_string_height
function.description: Determines the total height of a given nul-terminated string. This value is not generally useful, because you cannot determine how this total height will be drawn in relation to the baseline. See gdk_string_extents().
function.return: the height of the string in pixels.

function.name: gdk_query_visual_types
function.description:
This function returns the available visual types for the default screen. It's equivalent to listing the visuals (gdk_list_visuals()) and then looking at the type field in each visual, removing duplicates.
The array returned by this function should not be freed.

parameter.name: visual_types
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the available visual types

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of available visual types

function.name: gdk_screen_get_monitor_height_mm
function.description:
Gets the height in millimeters of the specified monitor.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: monitor_num
parameter.parameter_description: number of the monitor, between 0 and gdk_screen_get_n_monitors (screen)

function.return: the height of the monitor, or -1 if not available

function.name: gdk_display_close
function.description:
Closes the connection to the windowing system for the given display, and cleans up associated resources.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_image_get_width
function.description:
Determines the width of the image.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 2.22: #GdkImage should not be used anymore.
function.return: the width

function.name: gdk_query_depths
function.description:
This function returns the available bit depths for the default screen. It's equivalent to listing the visuals (gdk_list_visuals()) and then looking at the depth field in each visual, removing duplicates.
The array returned by this function should not be freed.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: return location for number of available depths

function.name: gdk_char_measure
function.description: Determines the distance from the origin to the rightmost portion of a character when drawn. This is not the correct value for determining the origin of the next portion when drawing text in multiple pieces.
function.return: the right bearing of the character in pixels.

function.name: gdk_spawn_on_screen
function.description:
Like g_spawn_async(), except the child process is spawned in such an environment that on calling gdk_display_open() it would be returned a #GdkDisplay with @screen as the default screen.
This is useful for applications which wish to launch an application on a specific screen.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: working_directory
parameter.parameter_description: child's current working directory, or %NULL to inherit parent's

parameter.name: envp
parameter.parameter_description: child's environment, or %NULL to inherit parent's

parameter.name: child_setup
parameter.parameter_description: function to run in the child just before exec()

parameter.name: child_pid
parameter.parameter_description: return location for child process ID, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE if error is set

function.name: gdk_keymap_map_virtual_modifiers
function.description:
Maps the virtual modifiers (i.e. Super, Hyper and Meta) which are set in @state to their non-virtual counterparts (i.e. Mod2, Mod3,...) and set the corresponding bits in @state.
This function is useful when matching key events against accelerators.
Since: 2.20

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to the modifier state to map

function.return: %TRUE if no virtual modifiers were mapped to the same non-virtual modifier. Note that %FALSE is also returned if a virtual modifier is mapped to a non-virtual modifier that was already set in @state.

function.name: gdk_window_get_modal_hint
function.description:
Determines whether or not the window manager is hinted that @window has modal behaviour.
Since: 2.22
function.return: whether or not the window has the modal hint set.

function.name: gdk_pixmap_foreign_new_for_screen
function.description:
Wraps a native pixmap in a #GdkPixmap. This may fail if the pixmap has been destroyed.
For example in the X backend, a native pixmap handle is an Xlib <type>XID</type>.
This function is an alternative to gdk_pixmap_foreign_new_for_display() for cases where the dimensions of the pixmap are known. For the X backend, this avoids a roundtrip to the server.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the width of the pixmap identified by @anid

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the height of the pixmap identified by @anid

parameter.name: depth
parameter.parameter_description: the depth of the pixmap identified by @anid

function.return: the newly-created #GdkPixmap wrapper for the native pixmap or %NULL if the pixmap has been destroyed.

function.name: gdk_set_sm_client_id
function.description:
Sets the <literal>SM_CLIENT_ID</literal> property on the application's leader window so that the window manager can save the application's state using the X11R6 ICCCM session management protocol.
See the X Session Management Library documentation for more information on session management and the Inter-Client Communication Conventions Manual (ICCCM) for information on the <literal>WM_CLIENT_LEADER</literal> property. (Both documents are part of the X Window System distribution.)

parameter.name: sm_client_id
parameter.parameter_description: the client id assigned by the session manager when the connection was opened, or %NULL to remove the property.

function.name: gdk_window_unstick
function.description: Reverse operation for gdk_window_stick(); see gdk_window_stick(), and gtk_window_unstick().

function.name: gdk_selection_property_get
function.description: Retrieves selection data that was stored by the selection data in response to a call to gdk_selection_convert(). This function will not be used by applications, who should use the #GtkClipboard API instead.

parameter.name: requestor
parameter.parameter_description: the window on which the data is stored

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: location to store a pointer to the retrieved data. If the retrieval failed, %NULL we be stored here, otherwise, it will be non-%NULL and the returned data should be freed with g_free() when you are finished using it. The length of the allocated memory is one more than the length of the returned data, and the final byte will always be zero, to ensure nul-termination of strings.

parameter.name: prop_type
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the type of the property.

parameter.name: prop_format
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the format of the property.

function.return: the length of the retrieved data.

function.name: gdk_visual_get_system
function.description: Get the system's default visual for the default GDK screen. This is the visual for the root window of the display. The return value should not be freed.
function.return: system visual

function.name: gdk_threads_add_timeout
function.description:
A wrapper for the common usage of gdk_threads_add_timeout_full() assigning the default priority, #G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT.
See gdk_threads_add_timeout_full().
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: interval
parameter.parameter_description: the time between calls to the function, in milliseconds (1/1000ths of a second)

function.return: the ID (greater than 0) of the event source.

function.name: gdk_x11_xatom_to_atom
function.description: Convert from an X atom for the default display to the corresponding #GdkAtom.

parameter.name: xatom
parameter.parameter_description: an X atom for the default GDK display

function.return: the corresponding G#dkAtom.

function.name: gdk_gc_set_clip_mask
function.description:
Sets the clip mask for a graphics context from a bitmap. The clip mask is interpreted relative to the clip origin. (See gdk_gc_set_clip_origin()).
Deprecated: 2.22: Use cairo_mask() instead.

function.name: gdk_drawable_get_screen
function.description:
Gets the #GdkScreen associated with a #GdkDrawable.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the #GdkScreen associated with @drawable

function.name: gdk_draw_text
function.description:
Draws a number of characters in the given font or fontset.
Deprecated: 2.4: Use gdk_draw_layout() instead.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the left edge of the text.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the baseline of the text.

parameter.name: text_length
parameter.parameter_description: the number of characters of @text to draw.

function.name: gdk_keymap_add_virtual_modifiers
function.description:
Adds virtual modifiers (i.e. Super, Hyper and Meta) which correspond to the real modifiers (i.e Mod2, Mod3, ...) in @modifiers. are set in @state to their non-virtual counterparts (i.e. Mod2, Mod3,...) and set the corresponding bits in @state.
GDK already does this before delivering key events, but for compatibility reasons, it only sets the first virtual modifier it finds, whereas this function sets all matching virtual modifiers.
This function is useful when matching key events against accelerators.
Since: 2.20

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to the modifier mask to change

function.name: gdk_x11_font_get_name
function.description: Return the X Logical Font Description (for font->type == GDK_FONT_FONT) or comma separated list of XLFDs (for font->type == GDK_FONT_FONTSET) that was used to load the font. If the same font was loaded via multiple names, which name is returned is undefined.
function.return: the name of the font. This string is owned by GDK and must not be modified or freed.

function.name: gdk_drawable_set_colormap
function.description: Sets the colormap associated with @drawable. Normally this will happen automatically when the drawable is created; you only need to use this function if the drawable-creating function did not have a way to determine the colormap, and you then use drawable operations that require a colormap. The colormap for all drawables and graphics contexts you intend to use together should match. i.e. when using a #GdkGC to draw to a drawable, or copying one drawable to another, the colormaps should match.

function.name: gdk_pixmap_colormap_create_from_xpm_d
function.description:
Create a pixmap from data in XPM format using a particular colormap.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use a #GdkPixbuf instead. You can use gdk_pixbuf_new_from_xpm_data() to create it. If you must use a pixmap, use gdk_pixmap_new() to create it and Cairo to draw the pixbuf onto it.

parameter.name: drawable
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkDrawable, used to determine default values for the new pixmap. Can be %NULL if @colormap is given.

parameter.name: colormap
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkColormap that the new pixmap will be use. If omitted, the colormap for @window will be used.

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a place to store a bitmap representing the transparency mask of the XPM file. Can be %NULL, in which case transparency will be ignored.

parameter.name: transparent_color
parameter.parameter_description: the color to be used for the pixels that are transparent in the input file. Can be %NULL, in which case a default color will be used.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a string containing the XPM data.

function.return: the #GdkPixmap.

function.name: gdk_region_offset
function.description: Moves a region the specified distance.

parameter.name: dx
parameter.parameter_description: the distance to move the region horizontally

parameter.name: dy
parameter.parameter_description: the distance to move the region vertically

function.name: gdk_window_clear_area
function.description: Clears an area of @window to the background color or background pixmap.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: x coordinate of rectangle to clear

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: y coordinate of rectangle to clear

function.name: gdk_window_get_parent
function.description:
Obtains the parent of @window, as known to GDK. Does not query the X server; thus this returns the parent as passed to gdk_window_new(), not the actual parent. This should never matter unless you're using Xlib calls mixed with GDK calls on the X11 platform. It may also matter for toplevel windows, because the window manager may choose to reparent them.
Note that you should use gdk_window_get_effective_parent() when writing generic code that walks up a window hierarchy, because gdk_window_get_parent() will most likely not do what you expect if there are offscreen windows in the hierarchy.
function.return: parent of @window

function.name: gdk_display_request_selection_notification
function.description:
Request #GdkEventOwnerChange events for ownership changes of the selection named by the given atom.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: selection
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkAtom naming the selection for which ownership change notification is requested

function.return: whether #GdkEventOwnerChange events will be sent.

function.name: gdk_display_sync
function.description:
Flushes any requests queued for the windowing system and waits until all requests have been handled. This is often used for making sure that the display is synchronized with the current state of the program. Calling gdk_display_sync() before gdk_error_trap_pop() makes sure that any errors generated from earlier requests are handled before the error trap is removed.
This is most useful for X11. On windowing systems where requests are handled synchronously, this function will do nothing.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_window_get_geometry
function.description:
Any of the return location arguments to this function may be %NULL, if you aren't interested in getting the value of that field.
The X and Y coordinates returned are relative to the parent window of @window, which for toplevels usually means relative to the window decorations (titlebar, etc.) rather than relative to the root window (screen-size background window).
On the X11 platform, the geometry is obtained from the X server, so reflects the latest position of @window; this may be out-of-sync with the position of @window delivered in the most-recently-processed #GdkEventConfigure. gdk_window_get_position() in contrast gets the position from the most recent configure event.
<note> If @window is not a toplevel, it is <emphasis>much</emphasis> better to call gdk_window_get_position() and gdk_drawable_get_size() instead, because it avoids the roundtrip to the X server and because gdk_drawable_get_size() supports the full 32-bit coordinate space, whereas gdk_window_get_geometry() is restricted to the 16-bit coordinates of X11. </note>

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: return location for X coordinate of window (relative to its parent)

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for Y coordinate of window (relative to its parent)

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: return location for width of window

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: return location for height of window

parameter.name: depth
parameter.parameter_description: return location for bit depth of window

function.name: gdk_visual_get_colormap_size
function.description:
Returns the size of a colormap for this visual.
Since: 2.22
function.return: The size of a colormap that is suitable for @visual.

function.name: gdk_pango_attr_stipple_new
function.description: Creates a new attribute containing a stipple bitmap to be used when rendering the text.

parameter.name: stipple
parameter.parameter_description: a bitmap to be set as stipple

function.return: new #PangoAttribute

function.name: gdk_window_has_native
function.description:
Checks whether the window has a native window or not. Note that you can use gdk_window_ensure_native() if a native window is needed.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the %window has a native window, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_window_raise
function.description:
Raises @window to the top of the Z-order (stacking order), so that other windows with the same parent window appear below @window. This is true whether or not the windows are visible.
If @window is a toplevel, the window manager may choose to deny the request to move the window in the Z-order, gdk_window_raise() only requests the restack, does not guarantee it.

function.name: gdk_drawable_get_display
function.description:
Gets the #GdkDisplay associated with a #GdkDrawable.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the #GdkDisplay associated with @drawable

function.name: gdk_window_set_hints
function.description:
This function is broken and useless and you should ignore it. If using GTK+, use functions such as gtk_window_resize(), gtk_window_set_size_request(), gtk_window_move(), gtk_window_parse_geometry(), and gtk_window_set_geometry_hints(), depending on what you're trying to do.
If using GDK directly, use gdk_window_set_geometry_hints().

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: logical OR of GDK_HINT_POS, GDK_HINT_MIN_SIZE, and/or GDK_HINT_MAX_SIZE

function.name: gdk_threads_add_timeout_seconds
function.description:
A wrapper for the common usage of gdk_threads_add_timeout_seconds_full() assigning the default priority, #G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT.
For details, see gdk_threads_add_timeout_full().
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: interval
parameter.parameter_description: the time between calls to the function, in seconds

function.return: the ID (greater than 0) of the event source.

function.name: gdk_window_is_input_only
function.description:
Determines whether or not the window is an input only window.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if @window is input only

function.name: gdk_window_lower
function.description:
Lowers @window to the bottom of the Z-order (stacking order), so that other windows with the same parent window appear above @window. This is true whether or not the other windows are visible.
If @window is a toplevel, the window manager may choose to deny the request to move the window in the Z-order, gdk_window_lower() only requests the restack, does not guarantee it.
Note that gdk_window_show() raises the window again, so don't call this function before gdk_window_show(). (Try gdk_window_show_unraised().)

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_default
function.description: Returns the #GdkKeymap attached to the default display.
function.return: the #GdkKeymap attached to the default display.

function.name: gdk_screen_broadcast_client_message
function.description:
On X11, sends an X ClientMessage event to all toplevel windows on @screen.
Toplevel windows are determined by checking for the WM_STATE property, as described in the Inter-Client Communication Conventions Manual (ICCCM). If no windows are found with the WM_STATE property set, the message is sent to all children of the root window.
On Windows, broadcasts a message registered with the name GDK_WIN32_CLIENT_MESSAGE to all top-level windows. The amount of data is limited to one long, i.e. four bytes.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: screen
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkScreen where the event will be broadcasted.

function.name: gdk_window_set_icon_list
function.description: Sets a list of icons for the window. One of these will be used to represent the window when it has been iconified. The icon is usually shown in an icon box or some sort of task bar. Which icon size is shown depends on the window manager. The window manager can scale the icon but setting several size icons can give better image quality since the window manager may only need to scale the icon by a small amount or not at all.

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: The #GdkWindow toplevel window to set the icon of.

parameter.name: pixbufs
parameter.parameter_description: A list of pixbufs, of different sizes.

function.name: gdk_gc_get_screen
function.description:
Gets the #GdkScreen for which @gc was created
Since: 2.2
function.return: the #GdkScreen for @gc.

function.name: gdk_cursor_new_from_pixbuf
function.description:
Creates a new cursor from a pixbuf.
Not all GDK backends support RGBA cursors. If they are not supported, a monochrome approximation will be displayed. The functions gdk_display_supports_cursor_alpha() and gdk_display_supports_cursor_color() can be used to determine whether RGBA cursors are supported; gdk_display_get_default_cursor_size() and gdk_display_get_maximal_cursor_size() give information about cursor sizes.
On the X backend, support for RGBA cursors requires a sufficently new version of the X Render extension.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkDisplay for which the cursor will be created

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the horizontal offset of the 'hotspot' of the cursor.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the vertical offset of the 'hotspot' of the cursor.

function.return: a new #GdkCursor.

function.name: gdk_gc_unref
function.description:
Decrement the reference count of @gc.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_unref() instead.

function.name: gdk_test_render_sync
function.description: This function retrives a pixel from @window to force the windowing system to carry out any pending rendering commands. This function is intended to be used to syncronize with rendering pipelines, to benchmark windowing system rendering operations.

function.name: gdk_window_set_user_data
function.description: For most purposes this function is deprecated in favor of g_object_set_data(). However, for historical reasons GTK+ stores the #GtkWidget that owns a #GdkWindow as user data on the #GdkWindow. So, custom widget implementations should use this function for that. If GTK+ receives an event for a #GdkWindow, and the user data for the window is non-%NULL, GTK+ will assume the user data is a #GtkWidget, and forward the event to that widget.

function.name: gdk_window_get_decorations
function.description: Returns the decorations set on the GdkWindow with #gdk_window_set_decorations

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: The toplevel #GdkWindow to get the decorations from

parameter.name: decorations
parameter.parameter_description: The window decorations will be written here

function.return: TRUE if the window has decorations set, FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_keymap_have_bidi_layouts
function.description:
Determines if keyboard layouts for both right-to-left and left-to-right languages are in use.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: keymap
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkKeymap or %NULL to use the default keymap

function.return: %TRUE if there are layouts in both directions, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gdk_pointer_grab_info_libgtk_only
function.description: Determines information about the current pointer grab. This is not public API and must not be used by applications.

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkDisplay for which to get the grab information

parameter.name: grab_window
parameter.parameter_description: location to store current grab window

parameter.name: owner_events
parameter.parameter_description: location to store boolean indicating whether the @owner_events flag to gdk_pointer_grab() was %TRUE.

function.return: %TRUE if this application currently has the pointer grabbed.

function.name: gdk_draw_line

parameter.name: x1_
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the start point.

parameter.name: y1_
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the start point.

parameter.name: x2_
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the end point.

parameter.name: y2_
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the end point.

function.name: gdk_drag_drop
function.description:
Drops on the current destination.
This function is called by the drag source.

function.name: gdk_window_input_shape_combine_mask
function.description:
Like gdk_window_shape_combine_mask(), but the shape applies only to event handling. Mouse events which happen while the pointer position corresponds to an unset bit in the mask will be passed on the window below @window.
An input shape is typically used with RGBA windows. The alpha channel of the window defines which pixels are invisible and allows for nicely antialiased borders, and the input shape controls where the window is "clickable".
On the X11 platform, this requires version 1.1 of the shape extension.
On the Win32 platform, this functionality is not present and the function does nothing.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: X position of shape mask with respect to @window

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: Y position of shape mask with respect to @window

function.name: gdk_event_get_screen
function.description:
Returns the screen for the event. The screen is typically the screen for <literal>event->any.window</literal>, but for events such as mouse events, it is the screen where the pointer was when the event occurs - that is, the screen which has the root window to which <literal>event->motion.x_root</literal> and <literal>event->motion.y_root</literal> are relative.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the screen for the event

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_render_pixmap_and_mask
function.description:
Creates a pixmap and a mask bitmap which are returned in the @pixmap_return and @mask_return arguments, respectively, and renders a pixbuf and its corresponding thresholded alpha mask to them. This is merely a convenience function; applications that need to render pixbufs with dither offsets or to given drawables should use gdk_draw_pixbuf() and gdk_pixbuf_render_threshold_alpha().
The pixmap that is created is created for the colormap returned by gdk_rgb_get_colormap(). You normally will want to instead use the actual colormap for a widget, and use gdk_pixbuf_render_pixmap_and_mask_for_colormap().
If the pixbuf does not have an alpha channel, then *@mask_return will be set to %NULL.

parameter.name: pixmap_return
parameter.parameter_description: Location to store a pointer to the created pixmap, or %NULL if the pixmap is not needed.

parameter.name: mask_return
parameter.parameter_description: Location to store a pointer to the created mask, or %NULL if the mask is not needed.

function.name: gdk_display_manager_list_displays
function.description:
List all currently open displays.
Since: 2.2
function.return: a newly allocated #GSList of #GdkDisplay objects. Free this list with g_slist_free() when you are done with it.

function.name: gdk_xid_table_lookup
function.description: Returns the Gdk object associated with the given X id for the default display.
function.return: the associated Gdk object, which may be a #GdkPixmap, a #GdkWindow or a #GdkFont or %NULL if no object is associated with the X id.

function.name: gdk_window_merge_child_input_shapes
function.description:
Merges the input shape masks for any child windows into the input shape mask for @window. i.e. the union of all input masks for @window and its children will become the new input mask for @window. See gdk_window_input_shape_combine_mask().
This function is distinct from gdk_window_set_child_input_shapes() because it includes @window's input shape mask in the set of shapes to be merged.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gdk_x11_screen_supports_net_wm_hint
function.description:
This function is specific to the X11 backend of GDK, and indicates whether the window manager supports a certain hint from the Extended Window Manager Hints Specification. You can find this specification on <ulink url="http://www.freedesktop.org">http://www.freedesktop.org</ulink>.
When using this function, keep in mind that the window manager can change over time; so you shouldn't use this function in a way that impacts persistent application state. A common bug is that your application can start up before the window manager does when the user logs in, and before the window manager starts gdk_x11_screen_supports_net_wm_hint() will return %FALSE for every property. You can monitor the window_manager_changed signal on #GdkScreen to detect a window manager change.
Since: 2.2
function.return: %TRUE if the window manager supports @property

function.name: gdk_window_begin_resize_drag
function.description: Begins a window resize operation (for a toplevel window). You might use this function to implement a "window resize grip," for example; in fact #GtkStatusbar uses it. The function works best with window managers that support the <ulink url="http://www.freedesktop.org/Standards/wm-spec">Extended Window Manager Hints</ulink>, but has a fallback implementation for other window managers.

parameter.name: edge
parameter.parameter_description: the edge or corner from which the drag is started

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the button being used to drag

parameter.name: root_x
