parameter.parameter_description: root window X coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: root_y
parameter.parameter_description: root window Y coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: timestamp of mouse click that began the drag (use gdk_event_get_time())

function.name: gdk_window_set_accept_focus
function.description:
Setting @accept_focus to %FALSE hints the desktop environment that the window doesn't want to receive input focus.
On X, it is the responsibility of the window manager to interpret this hint. ICCCM-compliant window manager usually respect it.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: accept_focus
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the window should receive input focus

function.name: gdk_cursor_get_display
function.description:
Returns the display on which the #GdkCursor is defined.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the #GdkDisplay associated to @cursor

function.name: gdk_image_get_height
function.description:
Determines the height of the image.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 2.22: #GdkImage should not be used anymore.
function.return: the height

function.name: gdk_draw_image
function.description:
Draws a #GdkImage onto a drawable. The depth of the #GdkImage must match the depth of the #GdkDrawable.
Deprecated: 2.22: Do not use #GdkImage anymore, instead use Cairo image surfaces.

parameter.name: xsrc
parameter.parameter_description: the left edge of the source rectangle within @image.

parameter.name: ysrc
parameter.parameter_description: the top of the source rectangle within @image.

parameter.name: xdest
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the destination within @drawable.

parameter.name: ydest
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the destination within @drawable.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the width of the area to be copied, or -1 to make the area extend to the right edge of @image.

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the height of the area to be copied, or -1 to make the area extend to the bottom edge of @image.

function.name: gdk_pointer_is_grabbed
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if the pointer on the default display is currently grabbed by this application.
Note that this does not take the inmplicit pointer grab on button presses into account.
function.return: %TRUE if the pointer is currently grabbed by this application.*

function.name: gdk_device_get_key
function.description:
If @index has a valid keyval, this function will fill in @keyval and @modifiers with the keyval settings.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the macro button to get.

function.name: gdk_window_set_composited
function.description:
Sets a #GdkWindow as composited, or unsets it. Composited windows do not automatically have their contents drawn to the screen. Drawing is redirected to an offscreen buffer and an expose event is emitted on the parent of the composited window. It is the responsibility of the parent's expose handler to manually merge the off-screen content onto the screen in whatever way it sees fit. See <xref linkend="composited-window-example"/> for an example.
It only makes sense for child windows to be composited; see gdk_window_set_opacity() if you need translucent toplevel windows.
An additional effect of this call is that the area of this window is no longer clipped from regions marked for invalidation on its parent. Draws done on the parent window are also no longer clipped by the child.
This call is only supported on some systems (currently, only X11 with new enough Xcomposite and Xdamage extensions). You must call gdk_display_supports_composite() to check if setting a window as composited is supported before attempting to do so.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: composited
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to set the window as composited

function.name: gdk_window_set_icon_name
function.description:
Windows may have a name used while minimized, distinct from the name they display in their titlebar. Most of the time this is a bad idea from a user interface standpoint. But you can set such a name with this function, if you like.
After calling this with a non-%NULL @name, calls to gdk_window_set_title() will not update the icon title.
Using %NULL for @name unsets the icon title; further calls to gdk_window_set_title() will again update the icon title as well.

function.name: gdk_image_get_image_type
function.description:
Determines the type of a given image.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 2.22: #GdkImage should not be used anymore.
function.return: the #GdkImageType of the image

function.name: gdk_pango_renderer_set_override_color
function.description:
Sets the color for a particular render part (foreground, background, underline, etc.), overriding any attributes on the layouts renderered with this renderer.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: part
parameter.parameter_description: the part to render to set the color of

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: the color to use, or %NULL to unset a previously set override color.

function.name: gdk_event_new
function.description:
Creates a new event of the given type. All fields are set to 0.
Since: 2.2
function.return: a newly-allocated #GdkEvent. The returned #GdkEvent should be freed with gdk_event_free().

function.name: gdk_window_reparent
function.description: Reparents @window into the given @new_parent. The window being reparented will be unmapped as a side effect.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: X location inside the new parent

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: Y location inside the new parent

function.name: gdk_string_to_compound_text_for_display
function.description:
Convert a string from the encoding of the current locale into a form suitable for storing in a window property.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkDisplay where the encoding is defined.

parameter.name: encoding
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the encoding atom (to be used as the type for the property).

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the format of the property

parameter.name: ctext
parameter.parameter_description: location to store newly allocated data for the property.

function.return: 0 upon success, non-zero upon failure.

function.name: gdk_drawable_get_colormap
function.description: Gets the colormap for @drawable, if one is set; returns %NULL otherwise.
function.return: the colormap, or %NULL

function.name: gdk_image_unref
function.description:
Deprecated function; use g_object_unref() instead.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_unref() instead.

function.name: gdk_display_supports_input_shapes
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if gdk_window_input_shape_combine_mask() can be used to modify the input shape of windows on @display.
Since: 2.10
function.return: %TRUE if windows with modified input shape are supported

function.name: gdk_window_get_events
function.description: Gets the event mask for @window. See gdk_window_set_events().
function.return: event mask for @window

function.name: gdk_pixmap_colormap_create_from_xpm
function.description:
Create a pixmap from a XPM file using a particular colormap.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use a #GdkPixbuf instead. You can use gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file() to create it. If you must use a pixmap, use gdk_pixmap_new() to create it and Cairo to draw the pixbuf onto it.

parameter.name: drawable
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkDrawable, used to determine default values for the new pixmap. Can be %NULL if @colormap is given.

parameter.name: colormap
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkColormap that the new pixmap will be use. If omitted, the colormap for @window will be used.

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a place to store a bitmap representing the transparency mask of the XPM file. Can be %NULL, in which case transparency will be ignored.

parameter.name: transparent_color
parameter.parameter_description: the color to be used for the pixels that are transparent in the input file. Can be %NULL, in which case a default color will be used.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: the filename of a file containing XPM data.

function.return: the #GdkPixmap.

function.name: gdk_window_set_transient_for
function.description:
Indicates to the window manager that @window is a transient dialog associated with the application window @parent. This allows the window manager to do things like center @window on @parent and keep @window above @parent.
See gtk_window_set_transient_for() if you're using #GtkWindow or #GtkDialog.

function.name: gdk_visual_get_bits_per_rgb
function.description:
Returns the number of significant bits per red, green and blue value.
Since: 2.22
function.return: The number of significant bits per color value for @visual.

function.name: gdk_events_pending
function.description: Checks if any events are ready to be processed for any display.
function.return: %TRUE if any events are pending.

function.name: gdk_gc_set_exposures
function.description:
Sets whether copying non-visible portions of a drawable using this graphics context generate exposure events for the corresponding regions of the destination drawable. (See gdk_draw_drawable()).
Deprecated: 2.22: There is no replacement. If you need to control exposures, you must use drawing operations of the underlying window system or use gdk_window_invalidate_rect(). Cairo will never generate exposures.

parameter.name: exposures
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE, exposure events will be generated.

function.name: gdk_screen_get_monitor_at_point
function.description:
Returns the monitor number in which the point (@x,@y) is located.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate in the virtual screen.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate in the virtual screen.

function.return: the monitor number in which the point (@x,@y) lies, or a monitor close to (@x,@y) if the point is not in any monitor.

function.name: gdk_window_set_modal_hint
function.description:
The application can use this hint to tell the window manager that a certain window has modal behaviour. The window manager can use this information to handle modal windows in a special way.
You should only use this on windows for which you have previously called gdk_window_set_transient_for()

parameter.name: modal
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the window is modal, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_drag_get_protocol_for_display
function.description:
Finds out the DND protocol supported by a window.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkDisplay where the destination window resides

parameter.name: xid
parameter.parameter_description: the windowing system id of the destination window.

parameter.name: protocol
parameter.parameter_description: location where the supported DND protocol is returned.

function.return: the windowing system id of the window where the drop should happen. This may be @xid or the id of a proxy window, or zero if @xid doesn't support Drag and Drop.

function.name: gdk_font_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count of a font by one.
function.return: @font

function.name: gdk_keyboard_grab_info_libgtk_only
function.description: Determines information about the current keyboard grab. This is not public API and must not be used by applications.

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: the display for which to get the grab information

parameter.name: grab_window
parameter.parameter_description: location to store current grab window

parameter.name: owner_events
parameter.parameter_description: location to store boolean indicating whether the @owner_events flag to gdk_keyboard_grab() was %TRUE.

function.return: %TRUE if this application currently has the keyboard grabbed.

function.name: gdk_pixmap_lookup
function.description:
Looks up the #GdkPixmap that wraps the given native pixmap handle.
For example in the X backend, a native pixmap handle is an Xlib <type>XID</type>.
function.return: the #GdkPixmap wrapper for the native pixmap, or %NULL if there is none.

function.name: gdk_draw_layout_line
function.description:
Render a #PangoLayoutLine onto an GDK drawable
If the layout's #PangoContext has a transformation matrix set, then @x and @y specify the position of the left edge of the baseline (left is in before-tranform user coordinates) in after-transform device coordinates.

parameter.name: drawable
parameter.parameter_description: the drawable on which to draw the line

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x position of start of string (in pixels)

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y position of baseline (in pixels)

function.name: gdk_display_peek_event
function.description:
Gets a copy of the first #GdkEvent in the @display's event queue, without removing the event from the queue. (Note that this function will not get more events from the windowing system. It only checks the events that have already been moved to the GDK event queue.)
Since: 2.2
function.return: a copy of the first #GdkEvent on the event queue, or %NULL if no events are in the queue. The returned #GdkEvent should be freed with gdk_event_free().

function.name: gdk_gc_set_rgb_bg_color
function.description:
Set the background color of a GC using an unallocated color. The pixel value for the color will be determined using GdkRGB. If the colormap for the GC has not previously been initialized for GdkRGB, then for pseudo-color colormaps (colormaps with a small modifiable number of colors), a colorcube will be allocated in the colormap.
Calling this function for a GC without a colormap is an error.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use gdk_cairo_set_source_color() instead.

function.name: gdk_window_move
function.description:
Repositions a window relative to its parent window. For toplevel windows, window managers may ignore or modify the move; you should probably use gtk_window_move() on a #GtkWindow widget anyway, instead of using GDK functions. For child windows, the move will reliably succeed.
If you're also planning to resize the window, use gdk_window_move_resize() to both move and resize simultaneously, for a nicer visual effect.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: X coordinate relative to window's parent

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: Y coordinate relative to window's parent

function.name: gdk_x11_window_move_to_current_desktop
function.description:
Moves the window to the correct workspace when running under a window manager that supports multiple workspaces, as described in the <ulink url="http://www.freedesktop.org/Standards/wm-spec">Extended Window Manager Hints</ulink>. Will not do anything if the window is already on all workspaces.
Since: 2.8

function.name: gdk_display_manager_get_default_display
function.description:
Gets the default #GdkDisplay.
Since: 2.2
function.return: a #GdkDisplay, or %NULL if there is no default display.

function.name: gdk_window_set_cursor
function.description: Sets the mouse pointer for a #GdkWindow. Use gdk_cursor_new_for_display() or gdk_cursor_new_from_pixmap() to create the cursor. To make the cursor invisible, use %GDK_BLANK_CURSOR. Passing %NULL for the @cursor argument to gdk_window_set_cursor() means that @window will use the cursor of its parent window. Most windows should use this default.

function.name: gdk_drop_finish
function.description:
Ends the drag operation after a drop.
This function is called by the drag destination.

parameter.name: success
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the data was successfully received.

function.name: gdk_window_thaw_toplevel_updates_libgtk_only
function.description:
Thaws a window frozen with gdk_window_freeze_toplevel_updates_libgtk_only().
This function is not part of the GDK public API and is only for use by GTK+.

function.name: gdk_window_maximize
function.description:
Maximizes the window. If the window was already maximized, then this function does nothing.
On X11, asks the window manager to maximize @window, if the window manager supports this operation. Not all window managers support this, and some deliberately ignore it or don't have a concept of "maximized"; so you can't rely on the maximization actually happening. But it will happen with most standard window managers, and GDK makes a best effort to get it to happen.
On Windows, reliably maximizes the window.

function.name: gdk_visual_get_depth
function.description:
Returns the bit depth of this visual.
Since: 2.22
function.return: The bit depth of this visual.

function.name: gdk_rectangle_intersect
function.description: Calculates the intersection of two rectangles. It is allowed for @dest to be the same as either @src1 or @src2. If the rectangles do not intersect, @dest's width and height is set to 0 and its x and y values are undefined. If you are only interested in whether the rectangles intersect, but not in the intersecting area itself, pass %NULL for @dest.

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the intersection of @src1 and @src2, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if the rectangles intersect.

function.name: gdk_window_process_all_updates
function.description: Calls gdk_window_process_updates() for all windows (see #GdkWindow) in the application.

function.name: gdk_window_set_skip_pager_hint
function.description:
Toggles whether a window should appear in a pager (workspace switcher, or other desktop utility program that displays a small thumbnail representation of the windows on the desktop). If a window's semantic type as specified with gdk_window_set_type_hint() already fully describes the window, this function should <emphasis>not</emphasis> be called in addition, instead you should allow the window to be treated according to standard policy for its semantic type.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_get_display_arg_name
function.description:
Gets the display name specified in the command line arguments passed to gdk_init() or gdk_parse_args(), if any.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the display name, if specified explicitely, otherwise %NULL this string is owned by GTK+ and must not be modified or freed.

function.name: gdk_region_get_rectangles
function.description: Obtains the area covered by the region as a list of rectangles. The array returned in @rectangles must be freed with g_free().

parameter.name: rectangles
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an array of rectangles

function.name: gdk_colormap_get_system_size
function.description: Returns the size of the system's default colormap. (See the description of struct #GdkColormap for an explanation of the size of a colormap.)
function.return: the size of the system's default colormap.

function.name: gdk_colormap_alloc_color
function.description: Allocates a single color from a colormap.

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: the color to allocate. On return the <structfield>pixel</structfield> field will be filled in if allocation succeeds.

parameter.name: writeable
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE, the color is allocated writeable (their values can later be changed using gdk_color_change()). Writeable colors cannot be shared between applications.

parameter.name: best_match
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE, GDK will attempt to do matching against existing colors if the color cannot be allocated as requested.

function.return: %TRUE if the allocation succeeded.

function.name: gdk_window_beep
function.description:
Emits a short beep associated to @window in the appropriate display, if supported. Otherwise, emits a short beep on the display just as gdk_display_beep().
Since: 2.12

function.name: gdk_screen_get_rgb_visual
function.description:
Gets a "preferred visual" chosen by GdkRGB for rendering image data on @screen. In previous versions of GDK, this was the only visual GdkRGB could use for rendering. In current versions, it's simply the visual GdkRGB would have chosen as the optimal one in those previous versions. GdkRGB can now render to drawables with any visual.
Since: 2.2
Deprecated: 2.22: Use gdk_screen_get_system_visual()
function.return: The #GdkVisual chosen by GdkRGB.

function.name: gdk_pango_context_get_for_screen
function.description:
Creates a #PangoContext for @screen.
The context must be freed when you're finished with it.
When using GTK+, normally you should use gtk_widget_get_pango_context() instead of this function, to get the appropriate context for the widget you intend to render text onto.
The newly created context will have the default font options (see #cairo_font_options_t) for the screen; if these options change it will not be updated. Using gtk_widget_get_pango_context() is more convenient if you want to keep a context around and track changes to the screen's font rendering settings.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: screen
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkScreen for which the context is to be created.

function.return: a new #PangoContext for @screen

function.name: gdk_xid_table_lookup_for_display
function.description:
Returns the GDK object associated with the given X id.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the associated Gdk object, which may be a #GdkPixmap, a #GdkWindow or a #GdkFont or %NULL if no object is associated with the X id.

function.name: gdk_app_launch_context_set_desktop
function.description:
Sets the workspace on which applications will be launched when using this context when running under a window manager that supports multiple workspaces, as described in the <ulink url="http://www.freedesktop.org/Standards/wm-spec">Extended Window Manager Hints</ulink>.
When the workspace is not specified or @desktop is set to -1, it is up to the window manager to pick one, typically it will be the current workspace.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: desktop
parameter.parameter_description: the number of a workspace, or -1

function.name: gdk_colormap_unref
function.description:
Deprecated function; use g_object_unref() instead.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_unref() instead.

function.name: gdk_screen_get_system_visual
function.description:
Get the system's default visual for @screen. This is the visual for the root window of the display. The return value should not be freed.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the system visual

function.name: gdk_window_remove_filter
function.description: Remove a filter previously added with gdk_window_add_filter().

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: user data for previously-added filter function

function.name: gdk_event_get_coords
function.description: Extract the event window relative x/y coordinates from an event.

parameter.name: x_win
parameter.parameter_description: location to put event window x coordinate

parameter.name: y_win
parameter.parameter_description: location to put event window y coordinate

function.return: %TRUE if the event delivered event window coordinates

function.name: gdk_event_send_clientmessage_toall
function.description:
Sends an X ClientMessage event to all toplevel windows on the default #GdkScreen.
Toplevel windows are determined by checking for the WM_STATE property, as described in the Inter-Client Communication Conventions Manual (ICCCM). If no windows are found with the WM_STATE property set, the message is sent to all children of the root window.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkEvent to send, which should be a #GdkEventClient.

function.name: gdk_draw_arc
function.description:
Draws an arc or a filled 'pie slice'. The arc is defined by the bounding rectangle of the entire ellipse, and the start and end angles of the part of the ellipse to be drawn.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use cairo_arc() and cairo_fill() or cairo_stroke() instead. Note that arcs just like any drawing operation in Cairo are antialiased unless you call cairo_set_antialias().

parameter.name: filled
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the arc should be filled, producing a 'pie slice'.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the left edge of the bounding rectangle.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the top edge of the bounding rectangle.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the width of the bounding rectangle.

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the height of the bounding rectangle.

parameter.name: angle1
parameter.parameter_description: the start angle of the arc, relative to the 3 o'clock position, counter-clockwise, in 1/64ths of a degree.

parameter.name: angle2
parameter.parameter_description: the end angle of the arc, relative to @angle1, in 1/64ths of a degree.

function.name: gdk_x11_cursor_get_xdisplay
function.description: Returns the display of a #GdkCursor.
function.return: an Xlib <type>Display*</type>.

function.name: gdk_pango_layout_get_clip_region
function.description:
Obtains a clip region which contains the areas where the given ranges of text would be drawn. @x_origin and @y_origin are the same position you would pass to gdk_draw_layout_line(). @index_ranges should contain ranges of bytes in the layout's text.
Note that the regions returned correspond to logical extents of the text ranges, not ink extents. So the drawn layout may in fact touch areas out of the clip region. The clip region is mainly useful for highlightling parts of text, such as when text is selected.

parameter.name: x_origin
parameter.parameter_description: X pixel where you intend to draw the layout with this clip

parameter.name: y_origin
parameter.parameter_description: Y pixel where you intend to draw the layout with this clip

parameter.name: index_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: array of byte indexes into the layout, where even members of array are start indexes and odd elements are end indexes

parameter.name: n_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: number of ranges in @index_ranges, i.e. half the size of @index_ranges

function.return: a clip region containing the given ranges

function.name: gdk_notify_startup_complete
function.description:
Indicates to the GUI environment that the application has finished loading. If the applications opens windows, this function is normally called after opening the application's initial set of windows.
GTK+ will call this function automatically after opening the first #GtkWindow unless gtk_window_set_auto_startup_notification() is called to disable that feature.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_drawable_get_image
function.description:
A #GdkImage stores client-side image data (pixels). In contrast, #GdkPixmap and #GdkWindow are server-side objects. gdk_drawable_get_image() obtains the pixels from a server-side drawable as a client-side #GdkImage. The format of a #GdkImage depends on the #GdkVisual of the current display, which makes manipulating #GdkImage extremely difficult; therefore, in most cases you should use gdk_pixbuf_get_from_drawable() instead of this lower-level function. A #GdkPixbuf contains image data in a canonicalized RGB format, rather than a display-dependent format. Of course, there's a convenience vs. speed tradeoff here, so you'll want to think about what makes sense for your application.
@x, @y, @width, and @height define the region of @drawable to obtain as an image.
You would usually copy image data to the client side if you intend to examine the values of individual pixels, for example to darken an image or add a red tint. It would be prohibitively slow to make a round-trip request to the windowing system for each pixel, so instead you get all of them at once, modify them, then copy them all back at once.
If the X server or other windowing system backend is on the local machine, this function may use shared memory to avoid copying the image data.
If the source drawable is a #GdkWindow and partially offscreen or obscured, then the obscured portions of the returned image will contain undefined data.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use @drawable as the source and draw to a Cairo image surface if you want to download contents to the client.
function.return: a #GdkImage containing the contents of @drawable

function.name: gdk_window_invalidate_rect
function.description: A convenience wrapper around gdk_window_invalidate_region() which invalidates a rectangular region. See gdk_window_invalidate_region() for details.

parameter.name: rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to invalidate or %NULL to invalidate the whole window

parameter.name: invalidate_children
parameter.parameter_description: whether to also invalidate child windows

function.name: gdk_window_resize
function.description:
Resizes @window; for toplevel windows, asks the window manager to resize the window. The window manager may not allow the resize. When using GTK+, use gtk_window_resize() instead of this low-level GDK function.
Windows may not be resized below 1x1.
If you're also planning to move the window, use gdk_window_move_resize() to both move and resize simultaneously, for a nicer visual effect.

function.name: gdk_device_get_state
function.description: Gets the current state of a device.

parameter.name: axes
parameter.parameter_description: an array of doubles to store the values of the axes of @device in, or %NULL.

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the modifiers, or %NULL.

function.name: gdk_device_get_has_cursor
function.description:
Determines whether the pointer follows device motion.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the pointer follows device motion

function.name: gdk_gc_ref
function.description:
Deprecated function; use g_object_ref() instead.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_ref() instead.
function.return: the gc.

function.name: gdk_draw_rectangle
function.description:
Draws a rectangular outline or filled rectangle, using the foreground color and other attributes of the #GdkGC.
A rectangle drawn filled is 1 pixel smaller in both dimensions than a rectangle outlined. Calling <literal>gdk_draw_rectangle (window, gc, TRUE, 0, 0, 20, 20)</literal> results in a filled rectangle 20 pixels wide and 20 pixels high. Calling <literal>gdk_draw_rectangle (window, gc, FALSE, 0, 0, 20, 20)</literal> results in an outlined rectangle with corners at (0, 0), (0, 20), (20, 20), and (20, 0), which makes it 21 pixels wide and 21 pixels high.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use cairo_rectangle() and cairo_fill() or cairo_stroke() instead. For stroking, the same caveats for converting code apply as for gdk_draw_line().

parameter.name: filled
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the rectangle should be filled.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the left edge of the rectangle.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the top edge of the rectangle.

function.name: gdk_window_set_group
function.description:
Sets the group leader window for @window. By default, GDK sets the group leader for all toplevel windows to a global window implicitly created by GDK. With this function you can override this default.
The group leader window allows the window manager to distinguish all windows that belong to a single application. It may for example allow users to minimize/unminimize all windows belonging to an application at once. You should only set a non-default group window if your application pretends to be multiple applications.

parameter.name: leader
parameter.parameter_description: group leader window, or %NULL to restore the default group leader window

function.name: gdk_x11_grab_server
function.description:
Call gdk_x11_display_grab() on the default display. To ungrab the server again, use gdk_x11_ungrab_server().
gdk_x11_grab_server()/gdk_x11_ungrab_server() calls can be nested.

function.name: gdk_keyval_convert_case
function.description: Obtains the upper- and lower-case versions of the keyval @symbol. Examples of keyvals are #GDK_a, #GDK_Enter, #GDK_F1, etc.

parameter.name: lower
parameter.parameter_description: return location for lowercase version of @symbol

parameter.name: upper
parameter.parameter_description: return location for uppercase version of @symbol

function.name: gdk_draw_point
function.description:
Draws a point, using the foreground color and other attributes of the #GdkGC.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use cairo_rectangle() and cairo_fill() or cairo_move_to() and cairo_stroke() instead.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the point.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the point.

function.name: gdk_display_store_clipboard
function.description:
Issues a request to the clipboard manager to store the clipboard data. On X11, this is a special program that works according to the freedesktop clipboard specification, available at <ulink url="http://www.freedesktop.org/Standards/clipboard-manager-spec"> http://www.freedesktop.org/Standards/clipboard-manager-spec</ulink>.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: clipboard_window
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkWindow belonging to the clipboard owner

parameter.name: targets
parameter.parameter_description: an array of targets that should be saved, or %NULL if all available targets should be saved.

function.name: gdk_x11_font_get_xdisplay
function.description: Returns the display of a #GdkFont.
function.return: an Xlib <type>Display*</type>.

function.name: gdk_visual_get_red_pixel_details
function.description:
Obtains values that are needed to calculate red pixel values in TrueColor and DirectColor. The "mask" is the significant bits within the pixel. The "shift" is the number of bits left we must shift a primary for it to be in position (according to the "mask"). Finally, "precision" refers to how much precision the pixel value contains for a particular primary.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: A pointer to a #guint32 to be filled in, or %NULL.

parameter.name: shift
parameter.parameter_description: A pointer to a #gint to be filled in, or %NULL.

parameter.name: precision
parameter.parameter_description: A pointer to a #gint to be filled in, or %NULL.

function.name: gdk_draw_trapezoids
function.description:
Draws a set of anti-aliased trapezoids. The trapezoids are combined using saturation addition, then drawn over the background as a set. This is low level functionality used internally to implement rotated underlines and backgrouds when rendering a PangoLayout and is likely not useful for applications.
Since: 2.6
Deprecated: 2.22: Use Cairo path contruction functions and cairo_fill() instead.

parameter.name: n_trapezoids
parameter.parameter_description: the number of trapezoids to draw

function.name: gdk_drawable_get_size
function.description:
Fills *@width and *@height with the size of @drawable. @width or @height can be %NULL if you only want the other one.
On the X11 platform, if @drawable is a #GdkWindow, the returned size is the size reported in the most-recently-processed configure event, rather than the current size on the X server.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: location to store drawable's width, or %NULL

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: location to store drawable's height, or %NULL

function.name: gdk_x11_screen_lookup_visual
function.description:
Looks up the #GdkVisual for a particular screen and X Visual ID.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the #GdkVisual (owned by the screen object), or %NULL if the visual ID wasn't found.

function.name: gdk_screen_get_primary_monitor
function.description:
Gets the primary monitor for @screen. The primary monitor is considered the monitor where the 'main desktop' lives. While normal application windows typically allow the window manager to place the windows, specialized desktop applications such as panels should place themselves on the primary monitor.
If no primary monitor is configured by the user, the return value will be 0, defaulting to the first monitor.
Since: 2.20
function.return: An integer index for the primary monitor, or 0 if none is configured.

function.name: gdk_win32_hdc_release
function.description: This function deallocates the Windows device context allocated by <funcion>gdk_win32_hdc_get()</function>. It should be called with the same parameters.

parameter.name: usage

function.name: gdk_display_supports_selection_notification
function.description:
Returns whether #GdkEventOwnerChange events will be sent when the owner of a selection changes.
Since: 2.6
function.return: whether #GdkEventOwnerChange events will be sent.

function.name: gdk_screen_get_display
function.description:
Gets the display to which the @screen belongs.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the display to which @screen belongs

function.name: gdk_visual_get_green_pixel_details
function.description:
Obtains values that are needed to calculate green pixel values in TrueColor and DirectColor. The "mask" is the significant bits within the pixel. The "shift" is the number of bits left we must shift a primary for it to be in position (according to the "mask"). Finally, "precision" refers to how much precision the pixel value contains for a particular primary.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: A pointer to a #guint32 to be filled in, or %NULL.

parameter.name: shift
parameter.parameter_description: A pointer to a #gint to be filled in, or %NULL.

parameter.name: precision
parameter.parameter_description: A pointer to a #gint to be filled in, or %NULL.

function.name: gdk_rgb_find_color
gdk_x11_screen_get_screen_number
function.description:
Returns the index of a #GdkScreen.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the position of @screen among the screens of its display.

function.name: gdk_drag_context_get_actions
function.description:
Determines the bitmask of actions proposed by the source if gdk_drag_context_suggested_action() returns GDK_ACTION_ASK.
Since: 2.22
function.return: the #GdkDragAction flags

function.name: gdk_threads_add_idle_full

parameter.name: priority

parameter.name: notify

function.name: gdk_draw_glyphs_transformed
function.description:
Renders a #PangoGlyphString onto a drawable, possibly transforming the layed-out coordinates through a transformation matrix. Note that the transformation matrix for @font is not changed, so to produce correct rendering results, the @font must have been loaded using a #PangoContext with an identical transformation matrix to that passed in to this function.
See also gdk_draw_glyphs(), gdk_draw_layout().
Since: 2.6
Deprecated: 2.22: Use pango_cairo_show_glyphs() instead.

parameter.name: matrix
parameter.parameter_description: a #PangoMatrix, or %NULL to use an identity transformation

parameter.name: font
parameter.parameter_description: the font in which to draw the string

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x position of the start of the string (in Pango units in user space coordinates)

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y position of the baseline (in Pango units in user space coordinates)

function.name: gdk_window_get_user_data
function.description: Retrieves the user data for @window, which is normally the widget that @window belongs to. See gdk_window_set_user_data().

function.name: gdk_x11_font_get_xfont
function.description: Returns the X font belonging to a #GdkFont.
function.return: an Xlib <type>XFontStruct*</type> or an <type>XFontSet</type>.

function.name: gdk_display_get_core_pointer
function.description:
Returns the core pointer device for the given display
Since: 2.2
function.return: the core pointer device; this is owned by the display and should not be freed.

function.name: gdk_x11_screen_get_monitor_output
function.description:
Gets the XID of the specified output/monitor. If the X server does not support version 1.2 of the RANDR extension, 0 is returned.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: monitor_num
parameter.parameter_description: number of the monitor, between 0 and gdk_screen_get_n_monitors (screen)

function.return: the XID of the monitor

function.name: gdk_notify_startup_complete_with_id
function.description:
Indicates to the GUI environment that the application has finished loading, using a given identifier.
GTK+ will call this function automatically for #GtkWindow with custom startup-notification identifier unless gtk_window_set_auto_startup_notification() is called to disable that feature.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: startup_id
parameter.parameter_description: a startup-notification identifier, for which notification process should be completed

function.name: gdk_window_redirect_to_drawable
function.description:
Redirects drawing into @window so that drawing to the window in the rectangle specified by @src_x, @src_y, @width and @height is also drawn into @drawable at @dest_x, @dest_y.
Only drawing between gdk_window_begin_paint_region() or gdk_window_begin_paint_rect() and gdk_window_end_paint() is redirected.
Redirection is active until gdk_window_remove_redirection() is called.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: width of redirection, or -1 to use the width of @window

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: height of redirection or -1 to use the height of @window

function.name: gdk_pango_attr_embossed_new
function.description: Creates a new attribute flagging a region as embossed or not.

parameter.name: embossed
parameter.parameter_description: if the region should be embossed

function.return: new #PangoAttribute

function.name: gdk_display_keyboard_ungrab
function.description:
Release any keyboard grab
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_net_wm_supports
function.description: This function is specific to the X11 backend of GDK, and indicates whether the window manager for the default screen supports a certain hint from the Extended Window Manager Hints Specification. See gdk_x11_screen_supports_net_wm_hint() for complete details.
function.return: %TRUE if the window manager supports @property

function.name: gdk_window_stick
function.description:
"Pins" a window such that it's on all workspaces and does not scroll with viewports, for window managers that have scrollable viewports. (When using #GtkWindow, gtk_window_stick() may be more useful.)
On the X11 platform, this function depends on window manager support, so may have no effect with many window managers. However, GDK will do the best it can to convince the window manager to stick the window. For window managers that don't support this operation, there's nothing you can do to force it to happen.

function.name: gdk_screen_get_system_colormap
function.description:
Gets the system's default colormap for @screen
Since: 2.2
function.return: the default colormap for @screen.

function.name: gdk_x11_xatom_to_atom_for_display
function.description:
Convert from an X atom for a #GdkDisplay to the corresponding #GdkAtom.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the corresponding #GdkAtom.

function.name: gdk_window_unmaximize
function.description:
Unmaximizes the window. If the window wasn't maximized, then this function does nothing.
On X11, asks the window manager to unmaximize @window, if the window manager supports this operation. Not all window managers support this, and some deliberately ignore it or don't have a concept of "maximized"; so you can't rely on the unmaximization actually happening. But it will happen with most standard window managers, and GDK makes a best effort to get it to happen.
On Windows, reliably unmaximizes the window.

function.name: gdk_draw_layout
function.description:
Render a #PangoLayout onto a GDK drawable
If the layout's #PangoContext has a transformation matrix set, then @x and @y specify the position of the top left corner of the bounding box (in device space) of the transformed layout.
If you're using GTK+, the usual way to obtain a #PangoLayout is gtk_widget_create_pango_layout().

parameter.name: drawable
parameter.parameter_description: the drawable on which to draw string

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X position of the left of the layout (in pixels)

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y position of the top of the layout (in pixels)

function.name: gdk_window_process_updates
function.description: Sends one or more expose events to @window. The areas in each expose event will cover the entire update area for the window (see gdk_window_invalidate_region() for details). Normally GDK calls gdk_window_process_all_updates() on your behalf, so there's no need to call this function unless you want to force expose events to be delivered immediately and synchronously (vs. the usual case, where GDK delivers them in an idle handler). Occasionally this is useful to produce nicer scrolling behavior, for example.

parameter.name: update_children
parameter.parameter_description: whether to also process updates for child windows

function.name: gdk_window_focus
function.description: Sets keyboard focus to @window. In most cases, gtk_window_present() should be used on a #GtkWindow, rather than calling this function.

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: timestamp of the event triggering the window focus

function.name: gdk_draw_segments
function.description:
Draws a number of unconnected lines.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use cairo_move_to(), cairo_line_to() and cairo_stroke() instead. See the documentation of gdk_draw_line() for notes on line drawing with Cairo.

parameter.name: segs
parameter.parameter_description: an array of #GdkSegment structures specifying the start and end points of the lines to be drawn.

parameter.name: n_segs
parameter.parameter_description: the number of line segments to draw, i.e. the size of the @segs array.

function.name: gdk_window_get_composited
function.description:
Determines whether @window is composited.
See gdk_window_set_composited().
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the window is composited.

function.name: gdk_window_begin_paint_region
function.description:
Indicates that you are beginning the process of redrawing @region. A backing store (offscreen buffer) large enough to contain @region will be created. The backing store will be initialized with the background color or background pixmap for @window. Then, all drawing operations performed on @window will be diverted to the backing store. When you call gdk_window_end_paint(), the backing store will be copied to @window, making it visible onscreen. Only the part of @window contained in @region will be modified; that is, drawing operations are clipped to @region.
The net result of all this is to remove flicker, because the user sees the finished product appear all at once when you call gdk_window_end_paint(). If you draw to @window directly without calling gdk_window_begin_paint_region(), the user may see flicker as individual drawing operations are performed in sequence. The clipping and background-initializing features of gdk_window_begin_paint_region() are conveniences for the programmer, so you can avoid doing that work yourself.
When using GTK+, the widget system automatically places calls to gdk_window_begin_paint_region() and gdk_window_end_paint() around emissions of the expose_event signal. That is, if you're writing an expose event handler, you can assume that the exposed area in #GdkEventExpose has already been cleared to the window background, is already set as the clip region, and already has a backing store. Therefore in most cases, application code need not call gdk_window_begin_paint_region(). (You can disable the automatic calls around expose events on a widget-by-widget basis by calling gtk_widget_set_double_buffered().)
If you call this function multiple times before calling the matching gdk_window_end_paint(), the backing stores are pushed onto a stack. gdk_window_end_paint() copies the topmost backing store onscreen, subtracts the topmost region from all other regions in the stack, and pops the stack. All drawing operations affect only the topmost backing store in the stack. One matching call to gdk_window_end_paint() is required for each call to gdk_window_begin_paint_region().

parameter.name: region
parameter.parameter_description: region you intend to draw to

function.name: gdk_x11_register_standard_event_type
function.description:
Registers interest in receiving extension events with type codes between @event_base and <literal>event_base + n_events - 1</literal>. The registered events must have the window field in the same place as core X events (this is not the case for e.g. XKB extension events).
If an event type is registered, events of this type will go through global and window-specific filters (see gdk_window_add_filter()). Unregistered events will only go through global filters. GDK may register the events of some X extensions on its own.
This function should only be needed in unusual circumstances, e.g. when filtering XInput extension events on the root window.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: event_base
parameter.parameter_description: first event type code to register

parameter.name: n_events
parameter.parameter_description: number of event type codes to register

function.name: gdk_color_to_string
function.description:
Returns a textual specification of @color in the hexadecimal form <literal>#rrrrggggbbbb</literal>, where <literal>r</literal>, <literal>g</literal> and <literal>b</literal> are hex digits representing the red, green and blue components respectively.
Since: 2.12
function.return: a newly-allocated text string

function.name: gdk_drag_drop_succeeded
function.description:
Returns whether the dropped data has been successfully transferred. This function is intended to be used while handling a %GDK_DROP_FINISHED event, its return value is meaningless at other times.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if the drop was successful.

function.name: gdk_colormap_query_color
function.description:
Locates the RGB color in @colormap corresponding to the given hardware pixel @pixel. @pixel must be a valid pixel in the colormap; it's a programmer error to call this function with a pixel which is not in the colormap. Hardware pixels are normally obtained from gdk_colormap_alloc_colors(), or from a #GdkImage. (A #GdkImage contains image data in hardware format, a #GdkPixbuf contains image data in a canonical 24-bit RGB format.)
This function is rarely useful; it's used for example to implement the eyedropper feature in #GtkColorSelection.

parameter.name: pixel
parameter.parameter_description: pixel value in hardware display format

parameter.name: result
parameter.parameter_description: #GdkColor with red, green, blue fields initialized

function.name: gdk_directfb_visual_by_format
function.description:
This function is specific to the DirectFB backend. It allows to specify a GdkVisual by @pixel_format.
At startup, only those visuals that can be blitted hardware-accelerated are registered. By using gdk_directfb_visual_by_format() you can retrieve visuals that don't match this criteria since this function will try to create a new visual for the desired @pixel_format for you.

parameter.name: pixel_format
parameter.parameter_description: the pixel_format of the requested visual

function.return: a pointer to the GdkVisual or %NULL if the pixel_format is unsupported.

function.name: gdk_text_property_to_utf8_list
function.description: Convert a text property in the giving encoding to a list of UTF-8 strings.

parameter.name: encoding
parameter.parameter_description: an atom representing the encoding of the text

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the list of strings or %NULL. The list should be freed with g_strfreev().

function.return: the number of strings in the resulting list.

function.name: gdk_unicode_to_keyval
function.description: Convert from a ISO10646 character to a key symbol.
function.return: the corresponding GDK key symbol, if one exists. or, if there is no corresponding symbol, wc | 0x01000000

function.name: gdk_x11_atom_to_xatom
function.description: Converts from a #GdkAtom to the X atom for the default GDK display with the same string value.
function.return: the X atom corresponding to @atom.

function.name: gdk_event_get_state
function.description: If the event contains a "state" field, puts that field in @state. Otherwise stores an empty state (0). Returns %TRUE if there was a state field in the event. @event may be %NULL, in which case it's treated as if the event had no state field.
function.return: %TRUE if there was a state field in the event

function.name: gdk_gc_get_colormap
function.description:
Retrieves the colormap for a given GC, if it exists. A GC will have a colormap if the drawable for which it was created has a colormap, or if a colormap was set explicitely with gdk_gc_set_colormap.
Deprecated: 2.22: There is no replacement. Cairo handles colormaps automatically, so there is no need to care about them.
function.return: the colormap of @gc, or %NULL if @gc doesn't have one.

function.name: gdk_display_open
function.description:
Opens a display.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: display_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the display to open

function.return: a #GdkDisplay, or %NULL if the display could not be opened.

function.name: gdk_window_restack
function.description:
Changes the position of @window in the Z-order (stacking order), so that it is above @sibling (if @above is %TRUE) or below @sibling (if @above is %FALSE).
If @sibling is %NULL, then this either raises (if @above is %TRUE) or lowers the window.
If @window is a toplevel, the window manager may choose to deny the request to move the window in the Z-order, gdk_window_restack() only requests the restack, does not guarantee it.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkWindow that is a sibling of @window, or %NULL

function.name: gdk_x11_get_xatom_name
function.description: Returns the name of an X atom for GDK's default display. This function is meant mainly for debugging, so for convenience, unlike <function>XAtomName()</function> and gdk_atom_name(), the result doesn't need to be freed. Also, this function will never return %NULL, even if @xatom is invalid.

parameter.name: xatom
parameter.parameter_description: an X atom for GDK's default display

function.return: name of the X atom; this string is owned by GTK+, so it shouldn't be modifed or freed.

function.name: gdk_display_beep
function.description:
Emits a short beep on @display
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_entries_for_keycode
function.description: Returns the keyvals bound to @hardware_keycode. The Nth #GdkKeymapKey in @keys is bound to the Nth keyval in @keyvals. Free the returned arrays with g_free(). When a keycode is pressed by the user, the keyval from this list of entries is selected by considering the effective keyboard group and level. See gdk_keymap_translate_keyboard_state().

parameter.name: keymap
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkKeymap or %NULL to use the default keymap

parameter.name: keys
parameter.parameter_description: return location for array of #GdkKeymapKey, or %NULL

parameter.name: keyvals
parameter.parameter_description: return location for array of keyvals, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if there were any entries

function.name: gdk_window_get_origin
function.description: Obtains the position of a window in root window coordinates. (Compare with gdk_window_get_position() and gdk_window_get_geometry() which return the position of a window relative to its parent window.)
function.return: not meaningful, ignore

function.name: gdk_window_get_window_type
function.description: Gets the type of the window. See #GdkWindowType.
function.return: type of window

function.name: gdk_gc_set_clip_region
function.description:
Sets the clip mask for a graphics context from a region structure. The clip mask is interpreted relative to the clip origin. (See gdk_gc_set_clip_origin()).
Deprecated: 2.22: Use gdk_cairo_region() and cairo_clip() in Cairo.

function.name: gdk_colormap_alloc_colors
function.description: Allocates colors from a colormap.

parameter.name: colors
parameter.parameter_description: The color values to allocate. On return, the pixel values for allocated colors will be filled in.

parameter.name: writeable
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE, the colors are allocated writeable (their values can later be changed using gdk_color_change()). Writeable colors cannot be shared between applications.

parameter.name: best_match
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE, GDK will attempt to do matching against existing colors if the colors cannot be allocated as requested.

parameter.name: success
parameter.parameter_description: An array of length @ncolors. On return, this indicates whether the corresponding color in @colors was successfully allocated or not.

function.return: The number of colors that were not successfully allocated.

function.name: gdk_screen_set_font_options
function.description:
Sets the default font options for the screen. These options will be set on any #PangoContext's newly created with gdk_pango_context_get_for_screen(). Changing the default set of font options does not affect contexts that have already been created.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: options
parameter.parameter_description: a #cairo_font_options_t, or %NULL to unset any previously set default font options.

function.name: gdk_region_shrink
function.description:
Resizes a region by the specified amount. Positive values shrink the region. Negative values expand it.
Deprecated: 2.22: There is no replacement for this function.

parameter.name: dx
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pixels to shrink the region horizontally

parameter.name: dy
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pixels to shrink the region vertically

function.name: gdk_event_put
function.description: Appends a copy of the given event onto the front of the event queue for event->any.window's display, or the default event queue if event->any.window is %NULL. See gdk_display_put_event().

function.name: gdk_colormap_get_system
function.description: Gets the system's default colormap for the default screen. (See gdk_colormap_get_system_for_screen ())
function.return: the default colormap.

function.name: gdk_window_is_destroyed
function.description:
Check to see if a window is destroyed..
Since: 2.18
function.return: %TRUE if the window is destroyed

function.name: gdk_visual_get_screen
function.description:
Gets the screen to which this visual belongs
Since: 2.2
function.return: the screen to which this visual belongs.

function.name: gdk_window_get_effective_parent
function.description:
Obtains the parent of @window, as known to GDK. Works like gdk_window_get_parent() for normal windows, but returns the window's embedder for offscreen windows.
See also: gdk_offscreen_window_get_embedder()
Since: 2.22
function.return: effective parent of @window

function.name: gdk_region_rect_equal
function.description:
Finds out if a regions is the same as a rectangle.
Since: 2.18
Deprecated: 2.22: Use gdk_region_new_rect() and gdk_region_equal() to achieve the same effect.
function.return: %TRUE if @region and @rectangle are equal.

function.name: gdk_drawable_ref
function.description:
Deprecated equivalent of calling g_object_ref() on @drawable. (Drawables were not objects in previous versions of GDK.)
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_ref() instead.
function.return: the same @drawable passed in

function.name: gdk_drawable_get_visible_region
function.description: Computes the region of a drawable that is potentially visible. This does not necessarily take into account if the window is obscured by other windows, but no area outside of this region is visible.
function.return: a #GdkRegion. This must be freed with gdk_region_destroy() when you are done.

function.name: gdk_gc_set_background
function.description:
Sets the background color for a graphics context. Note that this function uses @color->pixel, use gdk_gc_set_rgb_bg_color() to specify the background color as red, green, blue components.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use gdk_cairo_set_source_color() to use a #GdkColor as the source in Cairo. Note that if you want to draw a background and a foreground in Cairo, you need to call drawing functions (like cairo_fill()) twice.

function.name: gdk_drag_context_get_suggested_action
function.description:
Determines the suggested drag action of the context.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GdkDragAction value

function.name: gdk_window_move_resize
function.description: Equivalent to calling gdk_window_move() and gdk_window_resize(), except that both operations are performed at once, avoiding strange visual effects. (i.e. the user may be able to see the window first move, then resize, if you don't use gdk_window_move_resize().)

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: new X position relative to window's parent

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: new Y position relative to window's parent

function.name: gdk_screen_list_visuals
function.description:
Lists the available visuals for the specified @screen. A visual describes a hardware image data format. For example, a visual might support 24-bit color, or 8-bit color, and might expect pixels to be in a certain format.
Call g_list_free() on the return value when you're finished with it.
Since: 2.2
function.return: a list of visuals; the list must be freed, but not its contents

function.name: gdk_fontset_load_for_display
function.description:
Loads a fontset for use on @display.
The fontset may be newly loaded or looked up in a cache. You should make no assumptions about the initial reference count.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: fontset_name
parameter.parameter_description: a comma-separated list of XLFDs describing the component fonts of the fontset to load.

function.return: a #GdkFont, or %NULL if the fontset could not be loaded.

function.name: gdk_pointer_ungrab
function.description: Ungrabs the pointer on the default display, if it is grabbed by this application.

parameter.name: time_
parameter.parameter_description: a timestamp from a #GdkEvent, or %GDK_CURRENT_TIME if no timestamp is available.

function.name: gdk_window_set_type_hint
function.description:
The application can use this call to provide a hint to the window manager about the functionality of a window. The window manager can use this information when determining the decoration and behaviour of the window.
The hint must be set before the window is mapped.

parameter.name: hint
parameter.parameter_description: A hint of the function this window will have

function.name: gdk_x11_drawable_get_xid
function.description: Returns the X resource (window or pixmap) belonging to a #GdkDrawable.
function.return: the ID of @drawable's X resource.

function.name: gdk_x11_colormap_get_xdisplay
function.description: Returns the display of a #GdkColormap.
function.return: an Xlib <type>Display*</type>.

function.name: gdk_draw_rgb_32_image_dithalign
function.description:
Like gdk_draw_rgb_32_image(), but allows you to specify the dither offsets. See gdk_draw_rgb_image_dithalign() for more details.
Deprecated: 2.22: Cairo handles colors automatically.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: X coordinate on @drawable where image should go

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: Y coordinate on @drawable where image should go

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: width of area of image to draw

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: height of area of image to draw

function.name: gdk_window_set_background
function.description:
Sets the background color of @window. (However, when using GTK+, set the background of a widget with gtk_widget_modify_bg() - if you're an application - or gtk_style_set_background() - if you're implementing a custom widget.)
The @color must be allocated; gdk_rgb_find_color() is the best way to allocate a color.
See also gdk_window_set_background_pixmap().

function.name: gdk_keyboard_ungrab
function.description: Ungrabs the keyboard on the default display, if it is grabbed by this application.

parameter.name: time_
parameter.parameter_description: a timestamp from a #GdkEvent, or %GDK_CURRENT_TIME if no timestamp is available.

function.name: gdk_window_invalidate_region
function.description:
Adds @region to the update area for @window. The update area is the region that needs to be redrawn, or "dirty region." The call gdk_window_process_updates() sends one or more expose events to the window, which together cover the entire update area. An application would normally redraw the contents of @window in response to those expose events.
GDK will call gdk_window_process_all_updates() on your behalf whenever your program returns to the main loop and becomes idle, so normally there's no need to do that manually, you just need to invalidate regions that you know should be redrawn.
The @invalidate_children parameter controls whether the region of each child window that intersects @region will also be invalidated. If %FALSE, then the update area for child windows will remain unaffected. See gdk_window_invalidate_maybe_recurse if you need fine grained control over which children are invalidated.

function.name: gdk_x11_get_default_screen
function.description: Gets the default GTK+ screen number.
function.return: returns the screen number specified by the --display command line option or the DISPLAY environment variable when gdk_init() calls XOpenDisplay().

function.name: gdk_window_enable_synchronized_configure
function.description:
Indicates that the application will cooperate with the window system in synchronizing the window repaint with the window manager during resizing operations. After an application calls this function, it must call gdk_window_configure_finished() every time it has finished all processing associated with a set of Configure events. Toplevel GTK+ windows automatically use this protocol.
On X, calling this function makes @window participate in the _NET_WM_SYNC_REQUEST window manager protocol.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gdk_pixmap_lookup_for_display
function.description:
Looks up the #GdkPixmap that wraps the given native pixmap handle.
For example in the X backend, a native pixmap handle is an Xlib <type>XID</type>.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the #GdkPixmap wrapper for the native pixmap, or %NULL if there is none.

function.name: gdk_window_set_back_pixmap
function.description:
Sets the background pixmap of @window. May also be used to set a background of "None" on @window, by setting a background pixmap of %NULL.
A background pixmap will be tiled, positioning the first tile at the origin of @window, or if @parent_relative is %TRUE, the tiling will be done based on the origin of the parent window (useful to align tiles in a parent with tiles in a child).
A background pixmap of %NULL means that the window will have no background. A window with no background will never have its background filled by the windowing system, instead the window will contain whatever pixels were already in the corresponding area of the display.
The windowing system will normally fill a window with its background when the window is obscured then exposed, and when you call gdk_window_clear().

parameter.name: parent_relative
parameter.parameter_description: whether the tiling origin is at the origin of @window's parent

function.name: gdk_screen_get_rgba_colormap
function.description:
Gets a colormap to use for creating windows or pixmaps with an alpha channel. The windowing system on which GTK+ is running may not support this capability, in which case %NULL will be returned. Even if a non-%NULL value is returned, its possible that the window's alpha channel won't be honored when displaying the window on the screen: in particular, for X an appropriate windowing manager and compositing manager must be running to provide appropriate display.
This functionality is not implemented in the Windows backend.
For setting an overall opacity for a top-level window, see gdk_window_set_opacity().
Since: 2.8
function.return: a colormap to use for windows with an alpha channel or %NULL if the capability is not available.

function.name: gdk_display_supports_cursor_color
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if multicolored cursors are supported on @display. Otherwise, cursors have only a forground and a background color.
Since: 2.4
function.return: whether cursors can have multiple colors.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_render_threshold_alpha
function.description: Takes the opacity values in a rectangular portion of a pixbuf and thresholds them to produce a bi-level alpha mask that can be used as a clipping mask for a drawable.

parameter.name: bitmap
parameter.parameter_description: Bitmap where the bilevel mask will be painted to.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of region to threshold, or -1 to use pixbuf width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of region to threshold, or -1 to use pixbuf height

parameter.name: alpha_threshold
parameter.parameter_description: Opacity values below this will be painted as zero; all other values will be painted as one.

function.name: gdk_draw_layout_line_with_colors
function.description:
Render a #PangoLayoutLine onto a #GdkDrawable, overriding the layout's normal colors with @foreground and/or @background. @foreground and @background need not be allocated.
If the layout's #PangoContext has a transformation matrix set, then @x and @y specify the position of the left edge of the baseline (left is in before-tranform user coordinates) in after-transform device coordinates.

parameter.name: drawable
parameter.parameter_description: the drawable on which to draw the line

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x position of start of string (in pixels)

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y position of baseline (in pixels)

parameter.name: foreground

function.name: gdk_window_set_focus_on_map
function.description:
Setting @focus_on_map to %FALSE hints the desktop environment that the window doesn't want to receive input focus when it is mapped. focus_on_map should be turned off for windows that aren't triggered interactively (such as popups from network activity).
On X, it is the responsibility of the window manager to interpret this hint. Window managers following the freedesktop.org window manager extension specification should respect it.

parameter.name: focus_on_map
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the window should receive input focus when mapped

function.name: gdk_font_from_description
function.description: Load a #GdkFont based on a Pango font description. This font will only be an approximation of the Pango font, and internationalization will not be handled correctly. This function should only be used for legacy code that cannot be easily converted to use Pango. Using Pango directly will produce better results.
function.return: the newly loaded font, or %NULL if the font cannot be loaded.

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_entries_for_keyval
function.description: Obtains a list of keycode/group/level combinations that will generate @keyval. Groups and levels are two kinds of keyboard mode; in general, the level determines whether the top or bottom symbol on a key is used, and the group determines whether the left or right symbol is used. On US keyboards, the shift key changes the keyboard level, and there are no groups. A group switch key might convert a keyboard between Hebrew to English modes, for example. #GdkEventKey contains a %group field that indicates the active keyboard group. The level is computed from the modifier mask. The returned array should be freed with g_free().

parameter.name: keymap
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkKeymap, or %NULL to use the default keymap

parameter.name: keys
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an array of #GdkKeymapKey

parameter.name: n_keys
parameter.parameter_description: return location for number of elements in returned array

function.return: %TRUE if keys were found and returned

function.name: gdk_window_get_accept_focus
function.description:
Determines whether or not the desktop environment shuld be hinted that the window does not want to receive input focus.
Since: 2.22
function.return: whether or not the window should receive input focus.

function.name: gdk_x11_colormap_foreign_new
function.description:
If xcolormap refers to a colormap previously known to GTK+, returns a new reference to the existing #GdkColormap object, otherwise creates a new GdkColormap object and returns that
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: xcolormap
parameter.parameter_description: The XID of a colormap with visual @visual

function.return: the #GdkColormap object for @xcolormap. Free with g_object_unref(). Note that for colormap created with gdk_x11_colormap_foreign_new(), unref'ing the last reference to the object will only free the #GdkColoramp object and not call XFreeColormap()

To make the cursor invisible, use %GDK_BLANK_CURSOR.

function.description: Gets the bitwise OR of the currently active window state flags, from the #GdkWindowState enumeration.

function.name: gdk_list_visuals
function.description:
Lists the available visuals for the default screen. (See gdk_screen_list_visuals()) A visual describes a hardware image data format. For example, a visual might support 24-bit color, or 8-bit color, and might expect pixels to be in a certain format.
Call g_list_free() on the return value when you're finished with it.
function.return: a list of visuals; the list must be freed, but not its contents

function.name: gdk_window_coords_from_parent
function.description:
Transforms window coordinates from a parent window to a child window, where the parent window is the normal parent as returned by gdk_window_get_parent() for normal windows, and the window's embedder as returned by gdk_offscreen_window_get_embedder() for offscreen windows.
For normal windows, calling this function is equivalent to subtracting the return values of gdk_window_get_position() from the parent coordinates. For offscreen windows however (which can be arbitrarily transformed), this function calls the GdkWindow::from-embedder: signal to translate the coordinates.
You should always use this function when writing generic code that walks down a window hierarchy.
See also: gdk_window_coords_to_parent()
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: parent_x
parameter.parameter_description: X coordinate in parent's coordinate system

parameter.name: parent_y
parameter.parameter_description: Y coordinate in parent's coordinate system

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: return location for X coordinate in child's coordinate system

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for Y coordinate in child's coordinate system

gdk_devices_list

function.name: gdk_cairo_reset_clip
function.description:
Resets the clip region for a Cairo context created by gdk_cairo_create().
This resets the clip region to the "empty" state for the given drawable. This is required for non-native windows since a direct call to cairo_reset_clip() would unset the clip region inherited from the drawable (i.e. the window clip region), and thus let you e.g. draw outside your window.
This is rarely needed though, since most code just create a new cairo_t using gdk_cairo_create() each time they want to draw something.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gdk_draw_polygon

parameter.name: points
parameter.parameter_description: an array of #GdkPoint structures specifying the points making up the polygon.

If using GTK+, investigate gtk_window_set_default_icon_list() first, and then gtk_window_set_icon_list() and gtk_window_set_icon(). If those don't meet your needs, look at gdk_window_set_icon_list(). Only if all those are too high-level do you want to fall back to gdk_window_set_icon().

parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkWindow to use for the icon, or %NULL to unset

parameter.name: pixmap

function.name: gdk_beep
function.description: Emits a short beep on the default display.

function.name: gdk_fontset_load
function.description:
Loads a fontset.
The fontset may be newly loaded or looked up in a cache. You should make no assumptions about the initial reference count.

parameter.name: fontset_name
parameter.parameter_description: a comma-separated list of XLFDs describing the component fonts of the fontset to load.

function.return: a #GdkFont, or %NULL if the fontset could not be loaded.

function.name: gdk_window_unfullscreen
function.description:
Moves the window out of fullscreen mode. If the window was not fullscreen, does nothing.
On X11, asks the window manager to move @window out of the fullscreen state, if the window manager supports this operation. Not all window managers support this, and some deliberately ignore it or don't have a concept of "fullscreen"; so you can't rely on the unfullscreenification actually happening. But it will happen with most standard window managers, and GDK makes a best effort to get it to happen.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_window_freeze_updates
function.description: Temporarily freezes a window such that it won't receive expose events. The window will begin receiving expose events again when gdk_window_thaw_updates() is called. If gdk_window_freeze_updates() has been called more than once, gdk_window_thaw_updates() must be called an equal number of times to begin processing exposes.

function.name: gdk_device_get_name
function.description:
Determines the name of the device.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a name

function.name: gdk_screen_get_active_window
function.description:
Returns the screen's currently active window.
On X11, this is done by inspecting the _NET_ACTIVE_WINDOW property on the root window, as described in the <ulink url="http://www.freedesktop.org/Standards/wm-spec">Extended Window Manager Hints</ulink>. If there is no currently currently active window, or the window manager does not support the _NET_ACTIVE_WINDOW hint, this function returns %NULL.
On other platforms, this function may return %NULL, depending on whether it is implementable on that platform.
The returned window should be unrefed using g_object_unref() when no longer needed.
Since: 2.10
function.return: the currently active window, or %NULL.

Gets the preferred colormap for rendering image data on @screen. Not a very useful function; historically, GDK could only render RGB image data to one colormap and visual, but in the current version it can render to any colormap and visual. So there's no need to call this function.
Since: 2.2

function.return: the preferred colormap

Draws a string of characters in the given font or fontset.
